      const insertScript = (link) => {
        const scripts = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
        const script = document.createElement('script');
        script.src = link;
        script.type="text/javascript";
        scripts.parentNode.insertBefore(script,scripts);
     }
                  
      window.checkThirdPartyGoogle = (toggleName, brand, forceDefaultEnabled) => {
  const toggles = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(contents.getData("featureToggles", brand)) || {
    featureToggles: []
  }).featureToggles;
  let returnValue = true;

  try {
    const selectedToggle = toggles.find(toggle => toggle.name === toggleName);

    if (forceDefaultEnabled) {
      returnValue = selectedToggle === undefined ? false : selectedToggle.enabled;
    } else {
      returnValue = selectedToggle === undefined ? true : selectedToggle.enabled;
    }
  } catch (e) {
    console.log(e);
  }

  return returnValue;
};

CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Just a few of the big race highlights at Santa Anita are:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita Derby (Grade 1) – 3yo, 9 furlongs ($1,000,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+, 10 furlongs ($600,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 8½ furlongs ($400,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Margarita Invitational Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+ fillies & mares, 9 furlongs ($500,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t FrontRunner Stakes (Grade 1) – 2yo, 8½ furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t American Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 10 furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Stay Up to Date With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHead over to our \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fnews.tvg.com\u002Fcategory\u002Ftop-regions\u002Fsanta-anita-park\u002F\"\u003ESanta Anita News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E page to get the latest news updates!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Wager At Santa Anita With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Now you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. bonus!\u003C\u002Fp\u003E","seoContentReplaysTitle":"Horse Race Replays","raceTrackHubSA":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Address\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 285 Huntington Dr, Arcadia, CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Just a few of the big race highlights at Santa Anita are:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita Derby (Grade 1) – 3yo, 9 furlongs ($1,000,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+, 10 furlongs ($600,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 8½ furlongs ($400,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Margarita Invitational Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+ fillies & mares, 9 furlongs ($500,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t FrontRunner Stakes (Grade 1) – 2yo, 8½ furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t American Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 10 furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Stay Up to Date With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHead over to our \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fnews.tvg.com\u002Fcategory\u002Ftop-regions\u002Fsanta-anita-park\u002F\"\u003ESanta Anita News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E page to get the latest news updates!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Wager At Santa Anita With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Now you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. They will attain one after their first run.","previousWinnersTitle":"Previous Winners Running Today"},"seoMessages":{"raceTrackHubPIM":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Pimlico\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPimlico, within London in the City of Westminster, lent its name first to a pub (Olde Ben Pimlico’s Tavern) and then, due to English settlers, this age-old race track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSituated in Baltimore, Maryland, less than 10 miles from downtown Baltimore up the I-83 and under 20 miles to Baltimore\u002FWashington International Airport on the I-195, the track is within easy reach of a large population which helps bring in huge crowds every year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track hosts thoroughbred races and is of course famed for its part in the Triple Crown, hosting the Preakness Stakes each May. Pimlico is owned by the Maryland Jockey Club and is affectionately known as “Old Hilltop” owing to the infield rise which tends to play host to horsemen and the public alike.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPimlico History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPimlico Race Course opened way back in 1870 and is now an institution. A beautiful colt called Preakness won the inaugural running of the Dinner Party Stakes and he of course now provides his name to the middle leg of the American Triple Crown. The Preakness Stakes has been run here since 1873.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPimlico was the venue for the match-up between the amazing Seabiscuit and War Admiral in front of 43,000 people in the Pimlico Special back in 1938. The race was won by Seabiscuit.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Great Fire of Baltimore in 1904, Prohibition and the Great Depression of the 1930’s all left their mark on Pimlico but none have damaged it permanently as the track has ridden every wave coming its way over its long and illustrious career.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA peak was reached in 2007 when Preakness day brought about $87 million in bets on the day and an attendance at the track of an astonishing 121,263 people.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPimlico Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tAs is standard among top-level American tracks, Pimlico has a one-mile dirt oval track made up of loam and a seven-furlong turf track to the inner. There is a run of 1,150 feet from the final turn to the wire.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPimlico can host over 1,000 horses and, when the infield is open during the Preakness meet, more than 120,000 people too. Around half of the total capacity is housed in the infield in fact.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe Preakness meet takes place in May and features 12 days of living racing with the Mothers Day Buffet taking place on the Sunday before the big race.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFriday and Saturday of the Preakness meet feature the following races:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPreakness Stakes (Grade 1) – 9½ furlongs for 3yo’s, the middle leg of the Triple Crown\r\n\t\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\t Dinner Party Stakes (Grade 2) – 9 furlongs (turf), handicap for 3yo’s and older\r\n\t\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\t Black-Eyed Susan Stakes (Grade 2) – 9 furlongs for 3yo While the Tulsa State Fair attracts over one million patrons later each year, summertime horse racing at Fair Meadows is just one of many events offered throughout the year at the ever-expanding Expo Square. Races range in class from the lowest claiming price of $5,000 up to stakes races offered for each breed division. The stakes program is highlighted by the popular Futurities and Derby sponsored each year by Speedhorse. A state-of-the-art barn and paddock area is currently under construction and will be completed for the 2019 season.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSimulcast wagering is offered at the facility, and the legal gambling age in the state of Oklahoma is 18. River Downs is located adjacent to the Ohio River, and is easily accessible by boat. Racing surfaces include a one-mile dirt oval and seven-furlong turf course; the latter is the only greensward at any Ohio track. The 2-year-old gelding, Clang, defeated the 2-year-old filly, Myrtlewood, in a six-furlong match race at River Downs on October 12, 1935 with Clang's winning time of 1:09 1\u002F5 was a world record for the distance that stood for 12 years. Hall of Famer Discovery was a 12-length winner of the `35 Cincinnati Handicap at River Downs while fellow Hall of Famer Seabiscuit ran twice at River Downs in 1936, and was defeated both times. Situated next to the Oklahoma City Zoo and around 8 miles from the downtown area, the track is ideally placed. Remington has the distinction of being described as the first world class pari-mutuel race track in the state.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAmerican quarter horse, Appaloosa and Paint horses all feature during the meet running March through June while the very valuable thoroughbred season gets going in the fall.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track remains open on non-racing days for the purposes of simulcast racing, meaning bettors can wager on races from all around North America on a daily basis.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRemington Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tWith the need for a track in the area agreed in the 1980’s, shopping mall developer Edward J. DeBartolo set about building Remington Park which opened its doors to the public on the 1\u003Csup\u003Est \u003C\u002Fsup\u003E of September, 1988.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn its very first season in existence, Remington averaged a daily handle of $1.1million and attendance figures of 11,100 every day, quite a feat for a new track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tInnovation was at the forefront and from the outset Remington used a synthetic surface for its main track, a surface called Equitrack. The idea was that fast conditions would be in place for all races and for the track to handle all weathers; however it was actually the cruel Oklahoma sun which put paid to this experiment as the surface simply couldn’t hold up in the summer.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPretty soon Remington ripped up the Equitrack surface and decided to use a more traditional dirt surface and since then it has been a great success.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRemington’s experiment seemed to make sure all-weather surfaces had finished in America before they started however upon the installation of Polytrack at Turfway Park it’s clear now this could be revisited.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRemington Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track at Remington Park is a one-mile dirt oval, though they also have a seven furlong turf course laid to the inside.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe spring meet for mixed breeds is highlighted by the $1,000,000 Heritage Place Futurity in May while the fall meet’s main event for thoroughbreds is the $400,000 Oklahoma Derby.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Remington Park Bets With Us At TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Clock watchers can keep close tabs on those training at the Downs.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHosting meetings from May through September every racing season on \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Louisiana Downs has no shortage of thoroughbred action, though even on dark days the track shows racing action from around the world by way of the simulcast system.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBettors are invited in to place their wagers on all other tracks to keep the revenue coming in, though there is more than one way to have a bet here.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as hosting some quality thoroughbred and Quarter Horse racing, there are 1,300 slot machines inside Louisiana Downs making this another one of Americas ‘racinos’, catering for everyone who feels the need to have a wager or two.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLouisiana Downs is also a favorite of horsemen with top class facilities provided for riders, trainers and stable staff as well as the equine stars themselves.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLouisiana Downs History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tEdward J. DeBartolo Sr. of Cleveland, Ohio, known as a shopping center developer though always supporting the thoroughbred industry, built Louisiana Downs with the track’s first year of operation being back in 1974.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOver $23million was wagered in the Downs’ first year at an average of more than $75 a time but by the time the mid-80’s rolled around this figure was more like $224million at an average of $172 each proving that the areas of Shreveport and Bossier City needed such a facility.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPart of the reason for the high revenue at first was the busy schedule, with 125 days of racing at Louisiana Downs at its peak although that has settled to closer to 80 days of action now. Harrah’s Entertainment, owner of several other racetracks and casinos, bought Louisiana Downs in 2002.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn terms of big race days, Louisiana Downs is home to the Super Derby which is run every September (since 1980) over the Breeders’ Cup Classic distance of 1¼ miles and is the richest race held at the track with a purse of around $200,000 guaranteed.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe other big race on the calendar these days is the Tiznow Handicap over 1 1\u002F16 miles which is now part of the Breeders’ Cup Challenge series meaning the winner automatically qualifies for the Breeders’ Cup Dirt Mile in the fall.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLouisiana Downs Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is a one-mile dirt oval with a chute on the home stretch, with a seven-furlong turf course to the inside as standard.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSuper Derby – three-year-olds, on turf, 1 1\u002F16 miles, Grade 3 (September).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Tiznow Handicap – three-year-olds and over, 1 1\u002F16 miles (September).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager At Louisiana Downs With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you’re clued up on the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Stakes in August.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Arlington Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The story of Arlington Park goes back to 1927 when in October of that year it opened its doors to the public, around 20,000 people supporting the track for its first meet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA totalisator board was added in 1933 for pari-mutuel betting and by 1934 turf races has been added to the attractions. 1936 brought about photo-finishes as the facility quickly developed and by the 1940’s Arlington was already using electric starting gates.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTrifecta wagering and the first sponsored $100,000 race came in during 1971 and by 1981 it was hosting the first million dollar race, the Arlington Million.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tArlington’s international relations meant that in 1996 it hosted the American simulcasts of the Dubai World Cup, the first race in the world worth over $4million. The track also hosted the 2002 Breeders’ Cup Championships.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Arlington Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a nine-furlong Polytrack oval, a little larger than most dirt ovals in the States, which has chutes for races of varying lengths. The turf course is one mile around.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe turf course to the inside is one mile in length, made up of red fescue, Kentucky blue grass and perennial rye. April and October through December are quiet months but other than that it’s game on every day apart from Mondays and Tuesdays.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Balmoral Park\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Crete, Illinois is home to the once popular and very busy one-mile track of Balmoral Park which is under 30 miles from Joliet and less than 40 from downtown Chicago.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough in its past Balmoral Park hosted thoroughbred races it has been used for harness racing only since 1991. The grandstand can hold over 8,200 people with a further 2,000 hosted in the clubhouse.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBalmoral’s record racing handle came back in September 2000 and was registered at $2.8million while the biggest attendance at the track came ten years earlier with 11,494 people showing up on February 4\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E\r\n\tof that year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Balmoral Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Back in 1925, partners in the Kentucky Jockey Club and Churchill Downs bought up over 1,000 acres of land south of Crete, llinois to build a brand new race track which was to be called Lincoln Fields which became a popular thoroughbred venue until 1942 when it was shut down during World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tEven after the War, Lincoln Fields struggled to get back the races it had lost to Hawthorne and Washington Park but eventually it was reopened in 1954, once again for thoroughbred racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1955 a new Balmoral Jockey Club was formed which acquired Lincoln Fields and changed its name to Balmoral Park. The owners converted the one-mile track to a half-mile oval in order to use the venue as a harness racing track in 1967, though the one-mile track was added in 1989.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Illinois Racing board took away Balmoral Park’s thoroughbred license in 1991 and it became a harness only facility thereafter.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIt was announced in 2015 that the venue would close for racing, however it reopened in 2017 as a show jumping and show hunting facility, though racing could return at some point in the future.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Balmoral Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Balmoral has a one-mile dirt track fitted in 1989 with a fairly long stretch of almost 1,400 feet. 10 starters were allowed behind the gate on a track which is 80 feet wide.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Address\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 26435 S Dixie Hwy, Crete, IL 60417, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@hitsshows.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E","raceTrackHubHIA":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRacing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tQuarter horse racing dates are to be confirmed however there is a regular simulcast schedule with races from across the USA displayed most days. More details on upcoming races at Hialeah will appear on \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Hialeah Park\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Hialeah Park hosts its quarter horse races within a very historic setting, the site having been added to the US National Register of Historic Places back in 1979 with a further listed added in 1988.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe area of Hialeah is only 14 miles from Miami Beach and about the same from downtown Miami on the I-95, meaning access is good and the track can draw on huge communities which help to support it via race days and its on-site casino.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tHialeah Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe track at Hialeah Park opened up as far back as 1922 and was at the time a greyhound track. By 1925 though the Miami Jockey Club had launched thoroughbred races at the track and did so successfully until it was felt that an overhaul was needed and so the owners set about designing a new grandstand, clubhouse, gardens and a lake. The new facility was opened up to the public in 1932 complete with pari-mutuel betting.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter many years of success, the beautiful venue complete with its regular flamingo flocks was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1979.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBad news came in 2001 when Hialeah stopped hosting racing after a change in state law meant that it could no longer have exclusive dates, meaning competition with Calder and Gulfstream Park was too much to bear.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving not hosted any racing for over two years, Hialeah’s thoroughbred racing permit was revoked in 2004 and in 2007 the stables were demolished.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBetter news came in 2009 when owner John Brunetti was given a permit for racing and oversaw a $90million renovation project on the site. Later that year Hialeah Park was allowed to operate slot machines in its new casino and by November 28 quarter horse racing had begun.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHialeah’s status as a protected historic venue has in some way prohibited its progress, an overall $1billion project having been mooted to include a hotel, restaurant, stores and even a theater but put in doubt due to the lack of willingness to demolish areas of interest. As of now, quarter horse racing can continue using temporary stables.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tHialeah Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHialeah Park has a one-mile dirt oval with a chute down the home stretch. The richest quarter horse racing of all in fact is run here, the American Futurity, though plenty of prize money is on offer throughout the year for thoroughbreds too (see below).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe largest prizes are for the quarter horses round here however with the Grade 1 All American Derby, staged in early September, carrying a purse of almost $2,000,000.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003ESimulcast racing is on offer at the track allowing bettors to wager on races all around the country every day, while a casino sits on the site too offering table and video games which help greatly the revenue generated by Ruidoso Downs. The gaming facility is known as the Billy The Kid Casino.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe track sits 189 miles from the middle of Albuquerque up the I-25, another 136 miles from downtown El Paso and only 70 miles from Roswell though its own local community supports the facility very well.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ERuidoso History\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERuidoso Racetrack’s history is proof of the sort of ingenuity shown by people in their willingness to watch horse racing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe town of Ruidoso Downs suffered a flood in the 1940’s which led to fields being covered in silt and gravel and, in an opportunistic move, a rudimentary race track was formed on the surface. After this, around 1945,a rodeo stand was moved from the village of Captain, NM to the field where racing was taking place.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHaving become more professional over the years, the track was bought in 1953 and over the next ten years or so many expansions took place until in 1957 the All American Futurity was created for quarter horses.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter a partial change of ownership in 1988, millions of dollars were invested into Ruidoso which had fallen into disrepair and in 1989 simulcast wagering was offered at the facility for the first time, something which is vital these days to overall revenue.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA sales pavilion and sports theatre were built later and this is where the Ruidoso Select Yearling Sales are held every year to this day. A casino, adjacent to the main race track, was opened on site in 1999 and this has helped revenue greatly just as with most tracks around the country meaning prize money is in great shape at Ruidoso.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Ch2\u003ERuidoso Track Details\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERuidoso Downs has a one-mile dirt track and plenty of stabling for horses. There is no turf racing facility on the site which does not detract from the overall offering of the facility to racegoers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EBiggest Races\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003EMrs Jess Perry – $100,000 (June).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ERuidoso Sprint Handicap – $30,000 (June).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003ECorona Cartel – $100,000 (July).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EFirst Down Dash – $100,000 (September).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n \u003Cp\u003ERio Grande Senor Futurity Final – $175,000 (September).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAll American Juvenile – $200,000 (September).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Ruidoso Downs Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the New Mexico track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. But like all businesses, it has seen its ups and downs. With the advent of wide spread gaming casinos over the past two decades, the entire industry waned. Assiniboia with it. By 1993, bankruptcy was imminent and the future of racing in the region was bleak. That same year, however, the Assiniboia Downs Race Track passed from private ownership to become a non-profit corporation. The track`s fortunes started to climb under the leadership of Harvey Warner, a local businessman, and a dedicated board of directors.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tToday, the Manitoba Jockey Club continues to operate the Assiniboia Downs Racetrack as a non-profit organization. Though the racing calendar has been cut short – live horse racing is only held during the summer on the main track – the year-round simulcast broadcasts and warm hospitality of the staff keep players, fans, and tourists coming in droves. The facilities include a souvenir center, two restaurants, and 100 state-of-the-art VLTs for simulcast viewing.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\tAssiniboia Downs Racetrack has become a popular destination for a variety of conventions and family activities as well. The season here spreads out over two meets: one in spring and summer commencing on the second Wednesday in May and lasting until the fourth Sunday in July and another in fall running from the Friday after Labor Day until the fourth Sunday in October. A number of other important races in addition to the Belmont Stakes take place at Belmont Park. Top fillies race in the Mother Goose Stakes and the Coaching Club American Oaks, while the Bowling Green Handicap and Man O' War Stakes represent the track's most prestigious turf races.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the Belmont Park has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003EUpcoming Races\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftvg.com\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBelmont Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\tBelmont Park opened on May 4, 1905, nearly 40 years after the first Belmont Stakes took place. The race, which was named after its main financier, August Belmont Sr., immediately moved from Jerome Park Race Track to its new home, which August Belmont II helped build. With a few small exceptions, Belmont Race Track remained largely unchanged until after World War II. In the 1950s, the facility replaced its clubhouse and tore down the turreted Manice Mansion, which had housed the Belmont Turf and Field Club.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t In 1963, Belmont Park began a major overhaul of its massive grandstand after the structure was deemed unsafe. Reopening in 1968, the updated grandstand could accommodate 100,000 spectators, with seating for 33,000 of them and room for an additional 10,000 in the adjacent backyard. Today, Belmont remains one of the world's largest venues for horse racing and horse race betting. Some 120,139 spectators watched Smarty Jones try to cap off his Triple Crown bid here in 2004.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBelmont Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tKnown as \"Big Sandy,\" the main track at Belmont runs for 1 1\u002F2 miles, making it the longest dirt track for thoroughbreds in the United States. It features a straightaway chute that enables the running of 1 1\u002F8-mile races with a single turn. Inside of Big Sandy sit two turf courses: the 1 5\u002F16-mile Widener Turf Course and the 1 3\u002F16-mile Inner Turf Course. The former has one chute for 1 1\u002F16-mile races and another for 1-mile races. The Inner Turf Course also contains a chute for 1 1\u002F16-mile races.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Stay Up to Date With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHead over to our \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fnews.tvg.com\u002Fcategory\u002Fbelmont-park\u002F\"\u003EBelmont News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E page to get the latest news updates!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n         \u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAddress\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n        2150 Hempstead Turnpike, Elmont, NY 11003\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n","raceTrackHubSA":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Address\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 285 Huntington Dr, Arcadia, CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The facility is the only quarter horse racetrack in the area and currently runs a total of 35 dates with purses in excess of $5 million. Key stakes include the Alex Picov Memorial Futurity, the Alex Picov Memorial Championship (G3), and the Ontario Jackpot Futurity. The Ajax Downs Race Track also offers simulcasting of more than 40 of the most popular tracks from around the world and slot play on more than 800 machines in a newly renovated, 20,000 square foot casino.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Alex Picov, a savvy, kindhearted businessman from Ukraine, founded the Ajax Downs Racetrack more than three decades ago. After immigrating to Canada in 1921, he worked tirelessly in the horse industry in hopes of one day beginning his own business. More than 30 years later, he had purchased a homestead farm and looked to expand his farming and horse operations. In 1974, after nearly a decade of importing quarter horses from the U.S., the Picov family opened a horse complex in Ajax. The facility, which included an arena and tack shop, hosted horse shows early on. Years later, Picov Downs becameAjax Downs Racetrack and remains a must-see landmark of the Canadian frontier.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the Ajax Downs Racetrack has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. The track has become known as the “Winter Capital of Harness Racing”.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Pompano Park\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Pompano Park, known these days as Isle Casino Racing Pompano Park, hosts standardbred harness racing during the winter months which has become its niche due to the fantastic weather they enjoy in South Florida.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as its own busy harness racing schedule, Pompano simulcasts racing from all across North America on a daily basis which means regulars can wager on races all day, every day for all but two days of the year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as harness and thoroughbred racing, the simulcast offering includes greyhound racing from over 20 venues as well as jai-alai games from noon to midnight, or from 10AM for special events.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLike most successful tracks in the States, Pompano Park is these days operated as a “racino” with slot machines providing the bulk of the venture’s revenue as well as hosting live poker games. Some of the track’s revenue goes back into the community too, Pompano Park being a donor to Our Father’s House Soup Kitchen in Pompano Beach which is to their great credit.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track sits in a great location just 8 miles from downtown Fort Lauderdale, less than 40 miles from Miami Beach and within easy reach of two international airports.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Pompano Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Pompano Park have been racing since 1964 in their beautiful South Florida location which has become a favorite for trainers and drivers, seeing top action from both trotters and pacers. Back then the track was the brainchild of Frederick van Lennep who oversaw operations right up until his death in 1987.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBefore that however, an original track at Pompano stood on the same site having been built back in 1926 with the grand opening taking place on Christmas Day with huge crowds coming in to the area for the event.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRacing had to cease for a little while however after the Florida Governor branded those in charge of the track “law breakers” (as pari-mutuel betting was illegal back then). Further damage was caused, this time literally, in 1928 when a hurricane devastated the area and the site became dormant until 1953.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tVan Lennep though bought the land and envisaged a new track in the area and having balloted successfully in 1962 to have pari-mutuel betting made legal, his dream was finally to be realised.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Pompano Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t A standard 5\u002F8 mile dirt oval harness track is in situ at Pompano Park, the surface proving a popular one with drivers and trainers alike.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Address\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 777 Isle of Capri Circle, Pompano Beach, FL 33069, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Aaron Feinberg (aaron.feinberg@islecorp.com)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E","raceTrackHubPHI":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Parx Racing\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tFormerly known as Philadelphia Park, Parx Casino and Racing is not just a thoroughbred horse racing track but also the largest casino complex in the whole of Pennsylvania.\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t24-hour gaming is offered on site featuring 3,500 slot machines, 140 live table games and a 60-table poker room.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe racing is the main draw of course, with live racing action on 175 days of the year and also simulcast racing offered in order for horseplayers to wager on tracks all around the country every single day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tParx is home to Pennsylvania’s two most prestigious races, the $1,000,000 Pennsylvania Derby and the $500,000 Cotillion Handicap. The former originally served as a replacement on Memorial Day for the Jersey Derby after the grandstand at Garden State Park was destroyed.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThese days the Derby is run on the last Saturday in September, making it a stopping off point for some horses looking to get to the Breeders’ Cup in November.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tVisitors to Parx are certainly well catered for with 13 different dining and entertainment outlets on site situated in both main buildings including Parx East, an area open to the public since 2010.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tParx is in a handy position sitting only 16 miles from Trenton down the US-1 and less than 20 miles from downtown Philadelphia on the I-95 meaning attendances are not an issue.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EParx Racing History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tParx Racing has had a few incarnations, first of all as Keystone Racetrack upon opening in November 1974 when it replaced the old Liberty Bell Park as the area’s thoroughbred track.\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tUpon being sold in 1984 the track name was changed to Philadelphia Park after which a new turf course was installed at the site and by 1990 the track was sold again before simulcast racing was added.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn late August 2010 the track received its third name change in becoming Parx Racing and Casino and after this change some particularly prominent racehorses were seen strutting their stuff around this track, including Revidere and Spectacular Bid.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThose horses however pale into insignificance versus Smarty Jones, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner who made Parx his home and so narrowly missed out on a Triple Crown when running second in the Belmont Stakes.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EParx Racing Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tParx features a dirt oval one mile in length with chutes on both stretches. The seven furlong turf course sits, as usual, to the inside of the dirt track.\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tParx Dash Handicap (Grade 3) – five furlongs, three-year-olds and older (July).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\t Dr. James Penny Memoral Handicap (Grade 3) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, fillies, three-year-olds and older (July).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\t Turf Monster Handicap (Grade 3) – five furlongs (turf), three-year-olds and older (September).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\tPennsylvania Derby (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds (September).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u003E\r\n\t Cotillion Handicap (Grade 1) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-old fillies (September).\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Bets At Parx With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track at Parx, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Growth continued into the 50’s and by the 1960’s the track was considered one of the top ten in the country for harness racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough the raceway is still going strong today, it was back in 1966 that the all-time record attendance was set at Buffalo when just under 13,000 turned up on July 15 for a big summer meet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDuring this era the track was sold and new surface was constructed, made of stone dust which allowed for winter racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWhen in the 1970’s off-track betting was allowed Buffalo ensured they would not fall behind and introduced such facilities which, although seen as a plus in terms of revenue, led to a decline in attendances at the track itself hence the attendance record having stood since the 60’s.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere was another change of ownership in 1990 when Erie County Agricultural Society bought the facility, intending fully to intensify the program to keep the track as a quality harness racing venue.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tGiven the need for almost all US tracks to become racinos in order to look after income, Fairgrounds Gaming opened here in 2004 with over 900 gaming machines.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFollowing improvements year on year to the facilities for horsemen, the completion of the backstretch occurred in 2013 with more barns built and deal was later rescinded.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter more than a decade of racing both harness and thoroughbred meets, the track asked for only 25 thoroughbred dates in 2009 It wasn't until Maywood Park received Illinois' first harness racing license in 1946 that it built a track and began to stage wagering horse racing. In June of the following year, the venue offered the first full harness horse racing program to be televised in the U.S. Maywood Park installed a cutting-edge tote board in 1978 and set its own attendance record on September 27, 1980 when 20,133 spectators arrived at the venue.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Numerous champion standardbreds, such as Good Time, Albatross, and Sir Dalrae, have run the track here. The most recognizable champion to find the Winner's Circle here, though, was Muhammad Ali. \"The Greatest\" won a seven-furlong race as part of a fundraiser for Provident Hospital in 1979. In 1982, Maywood Park became the first Chicagoland track to host a Breeders Crown race. On December 21, 2001, the venue set a mutual handle horse race betting record when a total of $2,078,897 was wagered on evening races.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Maywood Park Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cstrong\u003EMaywood Park Race Track\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E contains a half-mile dirt oval and can seat more than 33,000 spectators. Maywood Park also offers a variety of options for dining while watching the action on the track. The Winner's Circle Dining Room provides tiered seating so that everyone has a prime view. Big-screen TVs, private carrels, and a full-service bar in the Saddle and Sulky Room create a top-notch atmosphere for horse race betting. The Super Booths give players a private atmosphere for betting and cheering on their horses. The twin spires atop the grandstands are the most recognizable architectural feature of Churchill Downs and are widely considered the symbol of the Derby. They were built in 1895. Churchill Downs Inc., the owner and operator of the horse racing track, lists the maximum occupancy of the facility at 50,000. However, on Derby Day, numbers can top 150,000.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the Churchill Downs Race Track has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003E\r\n\t\t Upcoming Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\"\u003E\r\n\t\t here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tChurchill Downs Race Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Churchill Downs Race Track was developed by Col. M. Lewis Clark in order to showcase the Kentucky breeding industry. While the first reference of Churchill Downs came in 1883, the\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fracetrackst\"\u003E\r\n\t\t horse racing track\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ewas made famous for hosting the Kentucky Derby since 1875. Today, Churchill Downs has expanded to 147 acres. It has also hosted the Kentucky Oaks and Breeders’ Cup on six occasions. In 2009, the Horseplayers Association of North America introduced a rating system for 65 Thoroughbred horse racing tracks in North America. The Churchill Downs Race Track was ranked #5 on this list.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Churchill Downs Race Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tChurchill Downs’ main dirt track is one mile in circumference, roughly 80 feet wide, with a 120-foot-wide section for the starting gate. A secondary turf track, inside the main dirt track, is 7\u002F8 of a mile in circumference and roughly 80 feet wide.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t In addition to the horse racing track, clubhouse, and stables, a main attraction of Churchill Downs is the museum, which highlights the history of the area. The race was not run anywhere else during the time when Kentucky Downs, then the Dueling Grounds, was closed but was re-introduced under its current title when the track reopened in 1998 as part of the Kentucky Cup Turf Festival.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs part of their commitment to innovation, Kentucky Downs in 2011 introduced Instant Racing, a game in which bettors can play at a terminal (almost like a slot machine) using racing data and video.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tKentucky Downs History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tA relatively new track, Kentucky Downs was built in 1990 and named Dueling Grounds based on the history of the farm on whose property the track was built.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn its early days the track was used only for steeplechasing, ever popular in England, Ireland and France, but with the fences removed the track went to flat racing only from 1992 though the chasing has returned infrequently over the years.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLike many tracks in the States Kentucky Downs went through its financial problems in the 90’s, eventually becoming so bad that the track missed its 1997 season before being used as a concert location.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn ’97 though the track was bought at auction by Churchill Downs and Turfway Park amongst others with the name at that point changing to Kentucky Downs and the track being designed to host a modest amount of racing fixtures each season.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tKentucky Downs Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe Downs’ turf course is just over a mile-and-a-quarter in length and is fairly unique for the States in that there is a slight right turn seven furlongs out before the gradual left turn towards the home stretch.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlong with Santa Anita, Kentucky Downs is one of only two tracks in the whole country to ask horses and riders to turn right at any stage. There is no dirt track at the venue.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tKentucky Cup Turf Stakes – three-year-olds and over, 1½ miles, Grade 3 (September).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Kentucky Cup Turf Dash – three-year-olds and over, 6 furlongs (September).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager At Kentucky Downs With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Connally Turf Cup and the Houston Ladies Classic taking place early in the season, both being Grade 3 races. All results will show \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults'\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Sam Houston\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSam Houston Race Park hosts both American Quarter Horse and Thoroughbred racing and is situated in northwest Houston, Texas.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSam Houston Park hosts a big community being less than a half hour from downtown Houston and serves as a multi-purpose venue which can handle concerts and festivals as well as racing during the off season. The track is located on Houston’s Beltway 8 between highway 290 and the I-45.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWith all thoroughbred racing taken care of by March, the American Quarter Horse season kicks in and runs until mid-May. From then on, Sam Houston is open for business as a venue for simulcast racing meaning horseplayers may attend and bet on races from venues all around the country, although the park is a popular concert venue too.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere are 125 betting machines available, all manned, as well as 100 self-service machines meaning the track can cater for plenty of bettors. On live race days, Sam Houston Park can house 1,224 horses.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDespite the track’s reputation as one of the fastest growing in the country, its largest ever handle was back in December 1999 on Texas Champions Day when a total of $4million was wagered.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSam Houston History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tUpon opening to the public on April 24, 1994, Sam Houston Race Park became the first top class horse racing facility in Texas.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe race park was named after Sam Houston, a former general and later president of the Republic of Texas and cost almost $100million to construct.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSince its inception back in ’94 the park has gone from strength to strength and is currently one of the fastest growing race tracks in the USA based on attendance figures over the past few years with a largest crowd figure of 32,177 in 2008.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSam Houston Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tBoth dirt and turf racing are important at Sam Houston Race Park, the dirt track being a one-mile oval with a 90-feet width on the straights and 80 feet around the turns and features two chutes. The dirt used for the racing surface was brought to the park from the Brazos River bottom.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe turf track, given that as usual it’s on the inside, is slightly shorter at 7\u002F8 of a mile and is changeable. In the summer months the turf track is made up of one-inch deep Hybrid Bermuda grass while in the winter this is Rye grass of the same depth.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe Houston Racing Festival hosted in January features six open stakes highlighted by the John B. Connally Turf Cup (Grade 3) – one-and-a-half miles (turf), four-year-olds and older, Houston Ladies Classic (Grade 3) – one mile and one-sixteenth, fillies and mares, four-year-olds and older and the Bob Bork Texas Turf Mile for three-year-olds going one mile (turf).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager On Races At Sam Houston With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track at Sam Houston, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. The complex is home to both the Keeneland Racecourse and its sales facility from which top class horses are purchased not just by US-based owners and trainers but from those as far afield as England, Ireland, France and Dubai.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tKeeneland’s standing was underlined in 2009 when the Horseplayers Association of North America introduced their rating system which placed it right at the top at number one. It is a designated National Historic Landmark.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tKeeneland History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe auctioning of horses as well as racing them goes to the very foundations of Keeneland, the facility having been built for this purpose as a non-profit organization back in 1936.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe racecourse itself has conducted the April and October meets since this time and has not broken with tradition with its spring meet one of the richest in North America to this day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDespite being rooted in tradition, the powers that be at Keeneland have not been scared of innovation over the years for example building a new trackside Winner’s Circle and creating the Queen Elizabeth II Challenge Cup Stakes in 1984 in honour of a visit from the lady herself.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe turf course was laid in 1985 and the following year received its status as a National Historic Landmark, something thoroughly deserved.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMoving away from traditional dirt, the main track at Keeneland became a synthetic Polytrack surface in 2006 but was restored to dirt in summer 2014, in time for the fall meet of that year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDespite its illustrious history and all it has done for worldwide racing, Keeneland had to wait until 2015 for its first Breeders’ Cup which it hosted successfully. The BC Classic that day was won by Triple Crown hero American Pharoah and despite some concerns over the size of the track the whole event was lauded by almost all who attended.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tKeeneland Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is just over a mile long, made up of dirt and surrounds a 7½ furlong turf course to its inside. The turf course actually uses more than one layout with the Keeneland Course having a temporary rail 15 feet out and the Haggin Course having no temporary rail.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tKeeneland has a very busy stakes calendar in its short meet, the important Grade One races being:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlcibiades Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Ashland Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Blue Grass Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Breeders’ Futurity Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t First Lady Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Jenny Wiley Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Madison Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Maker’s 46 Mile Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Queen Elizabeth II Challenge Cup Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Shadwell Turf Mile Stakes\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Spinster Stakes\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Bets At Keeneland With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the world famous facilities, don’t forget you can wager on races at Keeneland with TVG. The track sits only 8 miles from the center of El Paso, minutes from the Mexican border and 260 miles from Albuquerque.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough slot machines are in place at Sunland (some 700 of them these days), the casino does not offer any table casino games and also does not open 24 hours as per state regulation, though the racing is where it’s at anyway.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe traditional Sunland Park racing season runs from December to late in April and features both quarter horses and thoroughbreds. Simulcast racing is also offered meaning visitors can place wagers on races all around the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe highlight of the season is the Sunland Derby, a race which has reached Grade 3 level in the past. The Derby is worth $800,000 these days and is now used as a prep race for the Kentucky Derby in May. On the same card is the Sunland Park Oaks, this time for the fillies and with a purse of around $200,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough live thoroughbred racing is the highlight, the quarter horse season features a $400,000 Grade 1 race run over 440 yards in late December as well as a $300,000 race in April over 300 yards.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSunland Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t As of 1959 when it opened solely as a thoroughbred track, Sunland Park was the only legally operating gambling venue in the area for many years until legislation was eased.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tJust before the turn of the millennium, at a time when most US race tracks were seeing a decline in profits, Sunland Park was no different and did what most major venues have done and introduced slot machines at the venue following New Mexico legislators’ decision to allow the change.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs of now, Sunland has 700 slot machines providing revenue for the track meaning racing has improved significantly in recent years, average purses increasing from $35,000 daily back in the ‘90’s to around $250,000 now.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSunland Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main race track is a one-mile dirt oval made up of sandy loam. owners.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFrom that point, the facility was used only for private races and sometimes a flea market with the site in danger of becoming completely The following year, and it held the first Big Fresno Fair, with a five-day horse racing meet for trotters serving as the primary attraction. The California Legislature banned parimutuel horse race betting in 1909, and horse racing ceased at Fresno Race Track the next year.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Horse racing returned to Fresno Race Track in 1935. In 1938, the facility replaced its grandstand, but horse racing shut down again during World War II when the U.S. Army used the grounds for training. The venue repaired its grandstand in 1946, and the horses returned to the track two years later. Simulcast horse race betting becoming part of the offer in the 1980s, and numerous improvements over the years, including the addition of more than 6,100 trees and infield grass in 2008, have made the track a favorite among remote bettors.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFresno Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFresno Race Track features a one-mile dirt oval, and the distance from the last turn to the finish line measures 979 feet. The Brian I. Tatarian Grandstand can accommodate 5,125 spectators. The Luxury Deck on top of the grandstand offers an exclusive area for horse race betting, shaded tables, a complimentary buffet, and commanding views of the track and paddock. The track was built at a cost of around $7,000,000 which equates to more like $55,000,000 in today’s money, quite some investment for the area.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWith an initial track record of 2:00.4 set by a horse called Heineken, the two minute barrier was only broken at Pocono Downs 100 times between 1965 and 1981 as the track poses quite a test to runners.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough once again only a harness racing track these days, Pocono Downs did host thoroughbreds for ten years between 1970 and 1980 during a link-up at the time with the Shamrock Racing Association.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDuring this time, in 1972, the track closed briefly and was used as an evacuation center for residents who had been displaced by Hurricane Agnes.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn late 1996, Pocono Downs was sold for $47million which appears to show that it has held its value from way back when it was built in ’65 and continues to thrive.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPocono Downs Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPocono Downs features a 5\u002F8 mile harness racing track with a short 490-feet stretch.
