The inaugural meeting was hounded by unexpected bad weather however with rain falling on ten of the 11 days, though work was done to try to counteract this.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFittingly for this spectacle however, the closing night featured a race in which the mare Bart B S ran a world record performance, covering 400 yards in 20.3 seconds to the delight of the crowd.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1955 fans of quarter horse racing flocked to see Go Man Go, a superstar of the circuit whose appearance led to packed out seats in the grandstand and a great wagering handle.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWith the Vessels family having owned the track since its first ever meet, the 80’s and 90’s brought about great change with ownership moving around with great regularity until Ed Allred bought a 50% share in the track and things began to settle down.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1995 the Vessels Club was opened at a cost of $5,000,000 as well as that year heralding the beginning for the Los Alamitos $2million, a championship race for two-year-olds. Its huge purse meant that it has been recorded (in 2008) as being the richest race in the States outside of the Breeders’ Cup.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLos Alamitos Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThere is a one-mile dirt oval for thoroughbreds at Los Alamitos as well as a shorter, 5\u002F8 mile quarter horse track running through the site also. No turf track exists and none is required.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe Champion of Champions is \u003Cem\u003Ethe\u003C\u002Fem\u003E championship race for quarter horses, worth $750,000 and held over 440 yards each December at this track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Los Alamitos Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Cook donated 110 acres of land to the city for the purpose of developing a much needed pari-mutuel racing venue.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy ’92 the owners of Churchill Downs, home of the Kentucky Derby among other things, announced their plans to purchase the pari-mutuel license and open a track on the land which had been donated.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA contract was finally agreed in 1994 to construct Hoosier Park at an initial cost of around $13,000,000. By September, the track was open to the public and an initial crowd of 7,600 supported the grand opening while by the end of the calendar year the track had already announced plans to open their off-track betting facilities.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy the fall of the following year (’95) the first Indiana Derby was contested and the track was going from strength to strength, though in 1997 Churchill Downs took the decision to sell the park for over $8million.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn line with the way most of the country was heading, legislation was passed in 2007 to allow slot machines at the track in order to turn it into a racino. The windfall that the casino part of the facility generated allowed for bigger purses and better races on the track itself.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe casino had opened to the public in the summer of 2008 and has provided a great source of revenue to the track administrators, the horsemen and the state alike.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOne slightly sour note in the history of Hoosier Park is the loss of the Indiana Derby. After Indiana Downs was opened in 2001 at Shelbyville, the Derby was moved to that facility.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tHoosier Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe track at Hoosier Park is a 7\u002F8 mile dirt oval. Given the nature of the racing which takes place there, no turf track has been laid at the site.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Hoosier Park Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about Hoosier, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. not a huge community in itself, the track can be reached from Baltimore (105 miles away) or from Washington, DC (95 miles) meaning support is garnered from out of town race fans as well as locals.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EEver since its foundation back in 1969, Dover Downs has put on harness racing and these days also simulcasts races to off-track betting facilities right racing ever since.  Like many other tracks around the country there was a slowdown in revenue towards the 1990’s but in ’95 slot machines were introduced at the facility which greatly helped purse sizes on course.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 2002 there was somewhat of a split in the camp as the motor racing section of the business broke away to become Dover Motorsports Inc, however the name Dover Downs was retained for the popular race track and it continues to draw good crowds to this day.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ch2\u003EDover Downs Track Details Aqueduct\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t An oldie, but a goodie, Aqueduct, known as The Big A, opened up back in 1894 in Queens, New York although the original track was demolished in 1956 after 62 successful years. It is the only race track within New York City limits.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA new track and facilities were opened to the public in 1959 and in ’75 the inner track was laid in order for the venue to host winter time racing which is now a feature here.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOne of\r\n\t\u003Cem\u003E\r\n\t\t the\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\r\n\t key racing venues anywhere in North America, Aqueduct has hosted hundreds of top class races in its time and has contributed to the careers of many an equine star.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOver 17,000 people can be seated at Aqueduct for a total capacity of somewhere in excess of 40,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Aqueduct History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Since its inception in 1894, Aqueduct has been at the top of the racing game and it was made possible by the Queens County Jockey Club, something put together by Thomas Reilly.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOriginally owned by a family of Dutch settlers, the land was leased from them in order to accommodate the new track but it took until 1895 for it to be recognized by the Jockey Club. At this time, investment was allowed and so vast improvements were made.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMore land was purchased moving into the turn of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E\r\n\tcentury and by 1955 the old track was demolished to make way for a new world class facility. Costing $33million (around $284million in today’s money), the new facility was opened in fall 1959 to rapturous acclaim.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSince these times many a big race has been held at this venue and in 1985 the track deservedly hosted its first Breeders’ Cup Championships, though it has not hosted the event since.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Aqueduct Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a dirt oval of 9 furlongs which surrounds not one but two turf courses. Turfway Park, situated just on the city limits of Florence, right at Cincinnati\u002FNorthern Kentucky International Airport and less than 11 miles from the center of Cincinnati.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track’s two live thoroughbred meets are split into Holiday (December) and Winter\u002FSpring (details above) though the facility offers live simulcast racing all year round from all across North America, bettors welcomed into the track facility every day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBack in 2009, the now well recognised Horseplayers Association of North America introduced their ranking system for thoroughbred racetracks around the continent, Turfway in 2016 reaching number 11 on the ratings.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFamous Kentucky Derby racecaller Mike Battaglia is the caller at Turfway Park as well as other venues in the state and can be heard regularly on \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tTurfway Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe track opened up in Florence, Kentucky, way back in 1959 but was then named Latonia Race Course. The original Latonia, open from 1883 to 1939, hosted the Latonia Derby which at the time rivalled the now infamous Kentucky Derby. Turfway Park became the new name in 1986 upon the track’s change of ownership.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track was sold again in 1999 to a combination of Gtech (lottery equipment), Harrah’s Entertainment (owner of several racinos) and the not for profit Keeneland Association (operators of Lexington race track).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tUp until 2011 Turfway Park hosted the Kentucky Day of Champions, a prep meeting for the Breeders’ Cup Championships in November. The meet included five stakes races (four graded) including the Grade 2 Kentucky Cup Classic run a month before the Breeders’ Cup.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn terms of business interests, Turfway purchased and still retains a share in Kentucky Downs race track (formerly the Dueling Grounds) and has been willing to think outside the box in terms of their racing surface too.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRather than sticking with traditional dirt, in 2005 Turfway became the first North American track to install Polytrack, an “all-weather” synthetic surface developed in the UK. This surface eliminates weather problems pretty much meaning that Turfway’s going is always listed as “fast” regardless of weather.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 2012, ownership of Turfway changed slightly again with Keeneland’s stake being bought by Rock Gaming, then changing its name to JACK Entertainment with the integrity of the track not compromised.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tTurfway Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThere is no turf track at Turfway Park, ironically, however the dirk track is a one-mile oval made up of the synthetic surface Polytrack and featuring quarter-mile and 6½ furlong chutes and a 970 feet home stretch with stabling on site for 1,000 horses.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tJeff Ruby Steaks (Stakes) (Grade 3) – one 1\u002F8 miles, three-year-olds (March).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Bourbonette Oaks (Grade 3) – one mile, three-year-old fillies (March).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBet On Turfway Races Here With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about Turfway Park, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Connally Turf Cup and the Houston Ladies Classic taking place early in the season, both being Grade 3 races. All results will show \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults'\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Sam Houston\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSam Houston Race Park hosts both American Quarter Horse and Thoroughbred racing and is situated in northwest Houston, Texas.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSam Houston Park hosts a big community being less than a half hour from downtown Houston and serves as a multi-purpose venue which can handle concerts and festivals as well as racing during the off season. The track is located on Houston’s Beltway 8 between highway 290 and the I-45.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWith all thoroughbred racing taken care of by March, the American Quarter Horse season kicks in and runs until mid-May. From then on, Sam Houston is open for business as a venue for simulcast racing meaning horseplayers may attend and bet on races from venues all around the country, although the park is a popular concert venue too.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere are 125 betting machines available, all manned, as well as 100 self-service machines meaning the track can cater for plenty of bettors. On live race days, Sam Houston Park can house 1,224 horses.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDespite the track’s reputation as one of the fastest growing in the country, its largest ever handle was back in December 1999 on Texas Champions Day when a total of $4million was wagered.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSam Houston History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tUpon opening to the public on April 24, 1994, Sam Houston Race Park became the first top class horse racing facility in Texas.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe race park was named after Sam Houston, a former general and later president of the Republic of Texas and cost almost $100million to construct.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSince its inception back in ’94 the park has gone from strength to strength and is currently one of the fastest growing race tracks in the USA based on attendance figures over the past few years with a largest crowd figure of 32,177 in 2008.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSam Houston Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tBoth dirt and turf racing are important at Sam Houston Race Park, the dirt track being a one-mile oval with a 90-feet width on the straights and 80 feet around the turns and features two chutes. The dirt used for the racing surface was brought to the park from the Brazos River bottom.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe turf track, given that as usual it’s on the inside, is slightly shorter at 7\u002F8 of a mile and is changeable. In the summer months the turf track is made up of one-inch deep Hybrid Bermuda grass while in the winter this is Rye grass of the same depth.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tJohn B. Connally Turf Cup (Grade 3) – one-and-a-half miles (turf), four-year-olds and older (January).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Houston Ladies Classic (Grade 3) – one mile and a half furlong, fillies and mares, four-year-olds and older (January).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Maxxam Gold Cup – one mile and an eighth, four-year-olds and older (February).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager On Races At Sam Houston With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track at Sam Houston, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. There is a grandstand capable of seating 8,000 people with plenty more room in the open areas for bettors to move around comfortably and get a glimpse of the thoroughbreds.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn its young 21-year history over $1.7billion in bets have passed through the registers here and the fact that within 7 years of operation Lone Star Park hosted a Breeders’ Cup championship is testament to the standards they have set themselves, they are definitely to be applauded for that.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLone Star Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHaving had no racing to speak of in quite some time, Texans voted in favor of pari-mutuel horse racing to make a return to the state in late 1987.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWith all the donkey work done over the course of a long ten years, Lone Star Park opened on April 17, 1997 with a crowd of over 21,000 in attendance who between them wagered almost $1.5million on the day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIt was obvious by now that Texan bettors were releasing years of frustration at Lone Star who had the single most successful debut season in American racing history with $2.4million wagered each on average by on and off-track bettors.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs if that were not enough, Lone Star Park’s second season in 1998 became the first by a new track to increase attendances in its second year – quite a success.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWisely concentrating on horsemen and not just customers, Lone Star ensured they were attracting quality trainers and riders when the first phase of their expansion in 2002 ensured two new 50-stall barns were built as well as a 96-stall multipurpose barn and a dormitory building.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLone Star Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe dirt track itself is a one-mile oval with two 550-yard chutes and a seven-furlong turf course to its inside. There is a six degree banking on the turns and a 900-feet run to the wire from the final turn.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe 315-acre site can accommodate 1,600 horses on race day, housed in 32 different barns.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tTexas Mile Stakes – three-year-olds and older, 1 mile (April).\r\n\t\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tPremiere Stakes – three-year-olds and older, 6½ furlongs (April).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Lone Star Park Handicap – three-year-olds and older, 1 1\u002F16 miles (May).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about Lone Star Park, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. The Stockton Metropolitan Airport is only three miles away from the Fairgrounds.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as its race track and grandstand with seating for just under 4,000 people, the facility boasts four sales rings, 6 major buildings for exhibits and parking for 5,000 cars.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Fairgrounds facility opened back in 1994 and is one of 19 satellite wagering facilities in California.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOne of the major draw of the thoroughbred horse racing at this venue is that its six live racing days each year are made available free of charge (though parking is $5). Years later, ownership and operating rights were sold to E.P. Taylor, who played a key role in the upward development of the track and its promotion on a national stage. In fact, he was responsible for the creation of the Canadian Triple Crown with the second leg of the series, the Grade I Prince of Wales Stakes, being the Fort Erie’s major annual event.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Today, it’s considered one of the most picturesque tracks in North America. Horse racing fans can enjoy the scenery during 81 live racing days, May 1 through October 26, on weekends as well as Mondays and Tuesdays. The Fort Erie Race Track facility features a main track made of a sandy loam, measuring one-mile with a homestretch of more than 1,000 feet, as well as a turf course, measuring seven furlongs with 930 feet between the last turn and the finish line. The Fort Erie Racetrack grandstands can accommodate up to 4,000 spectators and the stables are capable of holding 1,000 horses. Beyond\r\nhorse racing, guests of the Fort Erie Racetrack can choose from three dining facilities, a variety of food stands, 75,000 square feet of gaming space, slot machines, as well as bars and live entertainment.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the Fort Erie Racetrack has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. The track sits 17 miles east of Harrisburg just off the I-81. The track sits within commutable distance to two other major cities; 100 miles from Philadelphia and Baltimore.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIts unique selling point is that it offers racing for 52 weeks of the year with the previous highlight being when it hosts the $200,000 Pennsylvania Governer’s Cup Handicap, a five-furlong sprint race on turf however the jewel in the crown now is the Penn Mile, run since 2013.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Penn Mile is a Grade 2 event on the turf for the three-year-olds, held each June and worth approximately $500,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPenn National History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe history of this great track stretches back to 1972 when the track raced for the first time in front of over 10,000 people on August 30.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPenn National had been the brainchild of a bunch of civic leaders from Central Pennsylvania who managed to establish the track very early with 100 racing dates in the first year alone – this is closer to 200 these days.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBack in ’83, Penn was instrumental in the invention of telephone betting, i.e. “account wagering” which went on to be a well practiced way of betting until the internet age took hold.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPenn National became a public company in 1994 when offering $18million worth of stock on the NASDAQ, something which has helped the business grow over the last 20-something years and has resulted in the track being able to host such races as the half-million dollar Penn Mile.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as providing a place for people in Pennsylvania to come and see live racing, Penn National had by 2000 opened 11 off-track betting facilities around the state which means bettors do not have to travel all the way to Grantville to place a wager.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPenn National Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is a one-mile dirt oval with two chutes and a seven-furlong turf course to the inside. revenue wisely from 1995 onwards, Delaware has managed to increase purse sizes for racing meaning a better class of horse turning up at the track which is to their great credit.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSuch stars of the game as Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro as well as Preakness and Belmont Stakes winner Afleet Alex have started their careers around here with Delaware now used as a permanent base for well bred horses running around New York and Florida, as well as Kentucky of course.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn mid-July $750,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs for location, the track is in a handy spot within easy access of the I-95 just 20 minutes from Wilmington and an hour from Philadelphia although out of town race goers come in less frequently these days.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tDelaware Park History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDelaware Park, one of twenty-three racetracks designed by William du Pont Jr., opened its doors officially on June 26, 1937 in order to host racing each year from May to October although it was in the planning for some time before this.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIts roots arguably go back as far as 1933 when legislation was passed to create the Delaware Racing Commission on the back of the state legalizing racing, this despite opposition at the time from conservatives.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving bought up a large chunk of land a Stanton, du Pont Jr. set about building a facility specifically for thoroughbred racing and this Delaware Park was born.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWhen Delaware Park first opened its doors back in ’37 the facilities consisted of an open-air, 7,500 seat grandstand which included a clubhouse on the upper deck – a far cry from today’s sprawling stands, marquees and huge crowds on Del Cap weekend.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAside from a brief closure during World War II, racing took off in the forties in Delaware and went from strength to strength over the subsequent decades until financial troubles forced the track’s closure in the fall of 1982.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy the spring of ’84 however we were back in business at Delaware and, despite the reduced amount of visitors from out of state due to the opening of tracks around New York and Maryland, the track flourished and today stands as a good breeding ground for potential Triple Crown stars with many permanently based there.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tDelaware Park Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe dirt track is a one mile oval States with racing of various forms having taken place in the area since the 1830’s, though the track opened officially in 1854.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFreehold is one of the most popular harness racing venues in the country with a leg of the Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers having taken place there between 1998 and 2010.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFreehold essentially runs two big meets per year, one starting on New Year’s Day running until the end of May and the other usually from September href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFreehold History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Although some historians say forms of racing have been held on this site as early as the 1830’s, it was in December 1853 that Monmouth County Agriculture Society was formed to hold an annual fair featuring harness racing in Freehold with the track opening officially in 1854.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy 1946, Freehold started a 24-day parimutuel meeting with a record crowd of 4,000 wagering more than $1.4million over the course of the 24 days.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn the 1950’s the track was sold for $5,000,000 and after 14 years of steady growth, 1962 saw a new record crowd of over 13,000 attending with over $25,000,000 wagered throughout the year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy 1965 Freehold had increased in value once again, being sold to Gibraltar Pari-Mutuel for over $8,000,000 with the new owners reconstructing the race track to allow for eight horses in each race rather than the previous six.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1970 the grandstand at Freehold was enclosed to allow year-round racing, something which has ensured the future of the track and by 1994 the venue was seen as valuable enough to be sold to International Thoroughbred Breeders for $23,000,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1999 the track was sold yet again, this time for as much The track is known for both thoroughbred and quarter horse racing but for the last few years has also hosted motorcycle racing during the off-season.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track is open on live racing ‘dark days’ for simulcast racing meaning bettors can attend and wager on races from tracks all around North America and beyond.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBeing situated right in Phoenix around 20 minutes from the downtown area, the track is capable of drawing good size crowds on live race days.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tTurf Paradise History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The area surrounding this track was once barren desert land, however racehorse owner and local businessman Walter Cluer had always dreamed of having a top class race track in Phoenix and so in 1954 he set about making that happen.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTurf Paradise’s doors opened to the public in 1956 to some acclaim and the architect of its success, Cluer, remained chief of the operation until 1980 when new owners took the reins and began to expand and modernize. Despite the name of the facility, it was only at this point that the turf course was laid to the inside the original dirt track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track’s third owner, Robert Walker, introduced off-track betting in 1989 and this meant more significant growth until in 1994 it was sold on and continued to go from strength to strength.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWhen the track was sold once more in the year 2000, it was by now worth a cool $53million with new owner Jerry Simms also putting his hand in his pocket to the tune of $5million to renovate the clubhouse and other facilities as well as adding race book style betting carrels, a new equine pool and improvements to the tracks themselves.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tField sizes began to increase, as did the track’s record for equine health, while Simms bought up more property around the facility. It opened in 1975 and offers fans live standardbred horse racing between September and May on a 5\u002F8ths mile harness track with homestretch of 677 feet, a speed rating of 2:004, a clubhouse capacity of 7,000 people, and seating for 19,000 fans in the grandstands. The casino features a gaming floor with 420 slots machines, a simulcast area, a wide variety of food and beverage in ten restaurants, and state of the art audio-visual technology.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tJim H. Keeling Sr., a native sportsman credited for bringing modern harness racing to British Columbia more than 50 years ago, is considered the founder of Fraser Downs Race Track. It began with a trip in 1969 to help the Fraser Valley Fair Board promote a harness meet. The journey and the people he met along the way led to his ownership of Cloverdale Raceway.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tAfter nearly 30 years of operation, Cloverdale Raceway underwent renovation and was renamed\r\nFraser Downs Racetrack. Then in 2003, when British Columbia abandoned its policy of banning slot machines from horse racing tracks, Chuck Keeling, Jim Keeling Sr.’s grandson, spearheaded a process to receive proper licensing to operate the slots – a move he believed could help arrest the sports decline and revive the Fraser Downs Racetrack.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tHe was right. Champion horses such as Cam Fella, Matts Scooter, Artsplace, Moni Maker, and Odies Fame, along with talented drivers such as Doug Brown, Steve Condren, Ron Waples, and John Campbell have thrilled racing fans over the years.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t After 35 years as Canada`s premier 5\u002F8ths mile harness oval, Mohawk Race Track was transformed during a massive $2 million summer overhaul. It reopened in 1998 as a one-of-a-kind 7\u002F8ths mile oval track made of crushed limestone, featuring 1,095 feet homestretch, ten starting gates, 730 stalls, and a seating capacity of 5,000. That same year, history was made again when Glory’s Comet, now the richest Canadian-bred horse ever, set the track record for trotters with a time 1:53.4. Then in September of 2000, two years after the renovation, Pacer Western Ideal became the fastest horse in Mohawk Racetrack\r\nhistory when he recorded a mile in 1:49.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Today,\r\n\t\tMohawk Racetrack regularly hosts a slew of fast-paced events. His presence spurred a bright future. A year later, riding a wave of positive press coverage, the ocean-side horseracing jewel hosted a $25,000 winner-take-all match race between the famed Seabiscuit and Ligaroti. The historic event turned out to be a media sensation as well, becoming the first nationwide broadcast of a Thoroughbred race by NBC Radio.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t As a result, the Del Mar Race Track was branded as the Saratoga of the West for summer racing. During the 1960s and 1970s, it was widely considered one of the premier race tracks in the country and became a playground for Hollywood stars as the track continued to grow in purses, handle, and attendance.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cstrong\u003E\r\n\t\tDel Mar Race Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDel Mar Race Track has a one-mile oval with chutes for 7\u002F8 and 1 1\u002F4 mile races and a seven-eighths mile oval with a diagonal straight away chute for 1 1\u002F16 and 1 1\u002F8 mile horse races. The\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftvg.com\u002Fracetracks\"\u003E\r\n\t\thorse racing track\u003C\u002Fa\u003E turf course is a combination of Common Bermuda and Hybrid Bermuda.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t More recently, the Del Mar Race Track underwent a major renovation to modernize facilities. Another renaming came in 1859 although not much was happening at the Creole Race Course until in 1863, when it became Fair Grounds, racing was scheduled during the Civil War.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFollowing a reopening of the aforementioned Metairie Course, Fair Grounds was once again closed in 1871 but quickly returned the following year under the guidance of the Louisiana Jockey Club.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRacing was banned in New Orleans in 1908, though the track survived hosting motor racing and in 1940 legislation was given to allow racing once again in the area. New investors saved the track from certain destruction in 1941 and ensured horse racing was to continue after World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA stable period followed and in 1981 the turf course was laid and then the facility sold on in 1990. Following a devastating fire a new grandstand had to be built in 1994 at a cost of $27 million, a grand reopening taking place on Thanksgiving Day 1997.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough further damaged by Hurricane Katrina, another Thanksgiving Day reopening occurred in 2006 and since then the track has run on an even keel and remains popular with traditional race goers.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFair Grounds Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThere is both a dirt oval and a turf course at Fair Grounds, both with very fair turns but no chutes.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSix Grade 2 races are held at Fair Grounds and they are the highlight of the meet. For the uninitiated; Quarter Horses are specifically an American breed which excels over\r\n\tshort distances.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThat was back in 1973 and once open the track hosted both Quarter Horse and Thoroughbred racing and was so successful that\r\n\tby the ‘90’s it was sold for $10million.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter law was passed allowing slot machines at Delta however the track was sold on again soon after, this time for a huge\r\n\t$100 million and, somewhat cruelly considering the owners invested more than $120 million in improvements\r\n\tat the site, was damaged in 2005 by Hurricane Rita.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter being closed for months after the hurricane Delta recovered and, much like at Delaware and other places these days,\r\n\tthe new found revenue from its slots and casino games allowed the track to improve racing on the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe winter program as it is now has helped the careers of several high quality horses in recent times, for example 2016 Delta\r\n\tJackpot Stakes winner Exaggerator which went on to win the Santa Anita Derby, the Haskell Invitational\r\n\tand over $3.5million in prize money.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tDelta Downs Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\r\n\tThe surface at Delta Downs is an interesting one; it has a limestone base with a mixture on top of clay and sand from the\r\n\tnearby Sabine River which helps to give this venue a real sense of place. The track is a six furlong\r\n\toval with an additional mile chute.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDelta can test the balance of a horse with its 10% incline on the turns and a quick home stretch of 660 yards long and 80\r\n\tfeet wide. The track also used to host standardbred harness racing, though that was shelved back in 1999 as management concentrated on thoroughbreds.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSimulcast wagering is offered at the site in order for bettors to punt on tracks all across the country, while Fairmount also operates four off-track betting facilities around Illinois (formerly five).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce the champion sprinter of North America, the excellent Smile was the winner of the 1985 Fairmount Derby under hall of fame jockey Jacinto Vasquez at this track and is remembered fondly by all at the venue.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFairmount Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tFairmount Park opened its doors to the public way back in 1925 and was seen as a success from the off. It was bought by the Ogden Corp in 1969 and again went from strength to strength for decades after that.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy the time 1997 rolled around, Fairmount Park had as many as 232 days of live racing in a year making it one of the busiest and most successful tracks anywhere in the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThis success started to wane as competition was supplied by the advent of the riverboat casinos in and around St Louis, meaning a drop in action. A few years ago racing dates had gone down to around 90 per year and now only 40 or so are planned in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter struggling to gain more race days on the track and also with putting slot machines and lottery terminals into the facility, Ogden eventually sold the facility in 2000 seemingly thinking the outlook was rather bleak. It’s all about quality rather than quantity these days though as the track is still going strong.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFairmount Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThere is a one-mile dirt oval at Fairmount with chutes for both six furlong and ten furlong races. the Mike Lee Stakes (Belmont), the New York Derby (Finger Lakes) and the Albany Stakes (Saratoga), all of which are for New York-bred horses only and carry purses of at least $125,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFinger Lakes History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tAs a standalone racetrack, Finger Lakes opened officially on May 23, 1962 for thoroughbreds and went through many ownership changes in its formative years.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track had its ups and downs in its early history too with the threat of bankruptcy seemingly never too far away and it was badly hurt financially when in the 80’s we saw the advent of off-track betting, meaning horseplayers no longer had to go to the track in order to place bets on the sport.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter simulcast racing was introduced though in the 1990’s Finger Lakes had a renaissance as they could open up every day to show racing and take bets from other tracks around the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThis recovery led to the track being valued at much more than in the past and in 2004 it was given a $10.5million renovation. The makeover led to Finger Lakes being the latest in a long line of ‘racinos’, in other words a casino and racetrack in one with a video gaming floor introduced inside the grandstand leading to much higher attendances and revenues.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA notable horse attached to Finger Lakes was Tin Cup Chalice who was the first winner of the Big Apple Triple, a series of races at Belmont and Saratoga as well as here.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTin Cup Chalice was based at Finger Lakes and was considered a local equine hero, but was also unfortunately killed at the track during training in 2009 when a colt called Zany, tragically well named, bolted before bumping into him with both horses destroyed in the incident.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tFinger Lakes Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is a one-mile oval with a quick 960 feet run-in. About Mountaineer\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The Mountaineer Casino, Racetrack and Resort to give it its full moniker, hosts thoroughbred racing in New Cumberland, WV but is well known for having started the trend of North American tracks becoming racinos as it was the first to be allowed slot machines at the facility.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough the track does sit in West Virginia, its closest major city is actually Pittsburgh which is only 50 miles away and provides a lot of the spectators regularly visiting this track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Mountaineer History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Having been the brainchild of a man whose family hailed from Waterford, Ireland, this track was originally named Waterford Downs and despite the company formed to build it having been incorporated back in 1937, construction didn’t begin until 1948 after World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWaterford Downs was renamed Waterford Park and it finally hosted its first day of live racing action in May 1951 and continued under the stewardship of the Boyle family until it was sold on in 1969.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving been sold again in 1987, the track became known as Mountaineer Park but once again the owners were to cash in as things improved and the facility was once again moved on, this time for $4 million cash as well as nearly $3 million in stock.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1994 Mountaineer became the first track in the country to be allowed to have slot machines at the facility making it the first Racino, something which has become common practice across the States as owners seek to bring in much needed revenue to increase purses on the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMountaineer’s casino offering was boosted in 2007 when 50 casino table games were introduced just before Christmas and there are now well over 3,000 slot machines on offer.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Mountaineer Track Today, the track is part of the Alameda County Fairgrounds. The three-week meet features thoroughbred, quarter horse, and Arabian races and serves as one of the stops on the colorful California Fairs racing circuit. Pleasanton stages a handful of stakes races, with the Oak Tree Handicap and Oak Tree Distaff representing the biggest of these by offering a purse of $100,000 each.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.alamedacountyfair.com\u002F2014fair\u002Fhorse_racing\u002FStart.php\"\u003E\r\n\t\tPleasanton Race Track\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003E\r\n\t\tUpcoming Races\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults\"\u003E\r\n\t\thorse race results\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPleasanton Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAugustin Bernal constructed Pleasanton Race Track in 1858, making it the oldest surviving horse racing track in the country today. Originally serving as a training track for the horses of local Spaniards, Pleasanton received its first grandstand in 1876 after Joseph Nevis purchased the venue. The track hosted the Golden Gate Fair in 1902 and the Pleasanton Fair and Races in 1904. The first modern Alameda County Fair took place here in 1912.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t California legalized parimutuel horse race betting in 1933, and mutuel wagering began at Pleasanton six years later. Two years after that, the track set a national record for average daily handle during its nine-day meet.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Pleasanton closed for three years during World War II, but the post-war era saw numerous developments at the track. The modern grandstand replaced the old wooden one in 1963, a nine-hole golf course supplanted the venue's inner racecourse in 1975, and a simulcast horse race betting facility opened in 1991. In recent years, Pleasanton's owners renovated the Palm Pavilion, which serves up highly-regarded cuisine to patrons and commanding views over the track and its thrilling clubhouse turn.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPleasanton Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPleasanton Race Track features a one-mile oval with one chute at 2 furlongs and the other at 6 furlongs. The homestretch measures 1,085-feet long and 60-feet wide. The grandstand seats about 6,700 spectators. The track sits on the 267-acre Alameda County Fairgrounds, which feature expansive grassy areas and hundreds of trees. In addition to putting on live racing, Pleasanton Race Track offers a simulcasting facility where fans can partake in horse race betting at tracks around the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAddress\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 4501 Pleasanton Avenue, Pleasanton, CA 94566\r\n","raceTrackHubSAR":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Saratoga Race Track\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Based in Saratoga Springs, New York, the Saratoga Race Track is the oldest organized sporting venue of any kind in the United States. John Hunter, who became the first chairman of The Jockey Club, and William R. Travers built the horse racing track in 1864, which has since played host to Travers Stakes, the oldest major Thoroughbred competition in the United States. Originally, Travers Stakes consisted of only four days. But over time it has lengthened. Today, it lasts six weeks, with races closing on Labor Day.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t To experience all that the Saratoga Race Track has to offer, along with 150 of the world’s best horse racing destinations, check out TVG. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003E\r\n\t\tUpcoming Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults\"\u003E\r\n\t\thorse race results\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSaratoga Race Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nyra.com\u002Fsaratoga\u002F\"\u003E\r\n\t\tSaratoga Race Track\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is steeped in history and tradition. In fact, Sports Illustrated rated it as the number 10 sports venue of the 20th Century in 1999. Saratoga has two popular nicknames – The Spa, named for the nearby mineral springs, and the Graveyard of Favorites, named for the historic upsets recorded there in years past. Perhaps most notable is Man o' War’s only defeat in 21 starts and Secretariat’s loss to The Onion after winning the Triple Crown.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tSaratoga Race Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere are three separate horse racing tracks at Saratoga: a main dirt track; an outer turf track known as the Mellon Turf Course, and an inner turf horse racing track. The main dirt track has a 1 1\u002F8 mile circumference, the Mellon Turf Course is a 1-mile turf track and the inner turf track is 7 furlongs. Additionally, there is the Oklahoma Track, used for warming-up and training.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAddress\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t 267 Union Avenue, Saratoga Springs, New York 12866","raceTrackHubOP":"\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Oaklawn Park\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tOaklawn Park stands as a premium, one-mile dirt thoroughbred track in Hot Springs, Arkansas. The racing season there runs from January to April when the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby takes place, a top class race in its own right but also a major stepping stone to the Kentucky Derby.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTop handicaps such as the Essex and the Razorback are run at Oaklawn as well as the Apple Blossom and the Rebel Stakes.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough situated in the town of Hot Springs, Oaklawn sits less than 300 miles from Dallas and 400 from Austin, Kansas City and Nashville meaning large crowds are attracted for big festivals.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tOaklawn Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tBack in 1905, the Hot Springs Mayor declared a half-day holiday for the opening of Oaklawn Park with over 3,000 people attending the track on its first day of racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tDue to political issues, no racing took place at Oaklawn between 1907 and 1916 but after a sustained period of action the now famous Arkansas Derby was inaugurated in 1936 with a purse of $5,000 offered to entrants.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy 1952 Oaklawn could boast daily attendances of almost 8,000 people and an average daily handle of well over $400,000, figures which rose by the turn of the decade to 10,000 and $500,000 respectively with the Arkansas Derby purse increasing to $50,000 by 1965.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track continued to go from strength to strength and during a 50-day meeting in 1970 an average of 11,000 people were attending daily with over $43,000,000 wagered over the course of the meet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn the mid-70’s Oaklawn gave birth to the Racing Festival of the South with pari-mutuel wagering amounting to a cool $80,000,000 that season and by the 80’s over a quarter of a million people were attending the festival each year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy now the purse for the Arkansas Derby was up at $500,000 and a new single-day attendance record was set with 71,000 showing up to see Rampage win the big race in 1986.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTen years later Arkansas Derby day saw a total handle of over $10.5million and by the turn of the millennium Oaklawn was still seeing increases in attendance and wagering meaning the track stands as one of the best in the country at present.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tOaklawn Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThere is no turf track at Oaklawn, however the dirt track is a one-mile oval with a home stretch of just over 1,000 feet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSouthwest Stakes (Grade 3) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds (February).\r\n\t\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tRebel Stakes (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds (March).\r\n\t\u003Cstrong\u003E\r\n\t\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\r\n\tApple Blossom Handicap (Grade 1) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, fillies and mares, four-year-olds and over (April).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Arkansas Derby (Grade 1) – one and 1\u002F8 miles, three-year-olds (April).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Oaklawn Handicap (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F8 miles, four-year-olds and older (April).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Fantasy Stakes (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds However, the track facilities are open 365 days a year for visitors to enjoy live simulcast racing from around the country, allowing bets to be placed on tracks anywhere in the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Clubhouse at Mahoning Valley offers various dining and drinking options as well as two main areas for wagering; the first floor and the Simulcast Teletheater up on the second floor.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe facilities for the horsemen at Mahoning Valley consist of 13 barns which together can stable almost 1,000 horses. Dorm areas are available for employees of trainers and owners with the building consisting of 84 rooms and a capacity of 168 people (based on two sharing a room).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track sits just 7 miles from Youngstown, Ohio, 65 miles from Cleveland and 75 miles over the state line to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and is accessible from the I-80 and the I-76.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tMahoning Valley History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tAnother of America’s newest inventions, the Racino, Mahoning Valley Race Course opened for business as recently as September 17, 2014 following an 18-month construction project which produced the track, a grandstand and a gaming area with almost 1,000 lottery terminals.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track was needed to replace Beulah Park in Columbus which closed for racing in May 2013. Racing began at Mahoning Valley on November 24, 2014 and now carries on October through April every year.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy the time Mahoning Valley raced for its second season it registered gains in both purses and wagering with the average daily purse being $76,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMore was to come though and during the 2015-16 season purses were averaging more than $106,000. This is a figure which means the track can compete with both Thistledown near Cleveland and Mountaineer Race Track over in West Virginia.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs of now, Mahoning Valley has three marquee open stakes races including the $200,000 Steel Valley Sprint Stakes, a six-furlong sprint for the three-year-olds in November. That age and distance has a resonance here with the other two big races being the Mahoning Distaff, also in November, and the Austintown Filly Sprint Stakes which takes place in April, each over the same six furlong trip and for three-year-olds only.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tMahoning Valley Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tMahoning Valley has a one-mile oval dirt track with 3% banking on the stretch and 6% in the turns which can test the balance of the runners. Following the final turn there is a 1,000 feet stretch run to the wire in front of the grandstand. There is no turf course at Mahoning Valley.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Steel Valley Sprint Stakes – three-year-olds, six furlongs (November).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Mahoning Distaff Stakes – three-year-old fillies and mares, six furlongs (November).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Austintown Filly Sprint Stakes – three-year-old fillies, six furlongs (April).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere are also ten stakes races for Ohio-bred animals, each worth $75,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Bets At Mahoning Valley With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Taylor Stakes and especially the Canadian International are three of Woodbine’s huge Grade 1 turf races, the latter being especially popular with European raiders who have been very successful in winning this race over the years.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRacing at Woodbine is well supported despite a huge TV audience for the big races with a record crowd of over 42,000 at the track, 13,000 accommodated in seated areas.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWoodbine is the only race track in the continent which is capable of staging both thoroughbred and standardbred horse racing on the same day, although the bulk of standardbred racing in the area is held at Mohawk Raceway in Campbellville.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track sits right by Toronto Pearson Airport in the city of Etobikoce, 18 miles from the middle of Toronto and around the same to Brampton.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWoodbine History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tRacing has been taking place at Woodbine since way back in 1874 when the original race track was opened at what was in those days the eastern outskirts of Toronto.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe action at the original site lasted for 82 years before the new (and current) facility was opened in 1956 and in 1994 after 120 years of thoroughbred racing, Woodbine began its harness racing program.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1976, Woodbine Racetrack was chosen as the venue for the summer Paralympics and in 1996 the track hosted the Breeders’ Cup Championships.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn the year 2000 slot machines, like at so many other tracks around North America, were introduced at Woodbine and with revenue high these days there is little sign of things abating at a track featuring five Grade 1 turf races.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWoodbine Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe one-and-a-half-mile turf track, made up of Kentucky Bluegrass, is the main draw at Woodbine and sits outside a synthetic “all-weather” track. The AW track is now made up of Tapeta, but for over a decade was Polytrack and before that it was standard dirt and is one mile long.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe standardbred track is even further inside and is 7\u002F8 of a mile in length, made up this time of crushed limestone.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSome huge races are run at Woodbine every year and you can read about the run-up to them on your \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog'\u003Eblog\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWoodbine Mile (Grade 1) – one mile (turf), three-year-olds and over (September).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Northern Dancer Turf Stakes (Grade 1) – 1½ miles (turf), three-year-olds and over (September).\r\n\t\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\tCanadian International Stakes (Grade 1) – 1½ miles (turf), three-year-olds and over (October).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t E.P. Taylor Stakes (Grade 1) – 1¼ miles (turf), three-year-olds and over (October).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Nearctic Stakes (Grade 1) – six furlongs (turf), three-year-olds and over (October).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Woodbine Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the famous track at Woodbine, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Live racing takes a break in July but other than that, there are races every month with the track also open on selected days for simulcast racing from around the country.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Golden Gate Fields\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tGolden Gate Fields has a loyal following in and around Berkeley and wider San Francisco having been on the go since 1941 when the first meeting was held.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tGGF is proud of its facilities including the Turf Club Restaurant in which visitors get not only a great view of the racing action, but also of the San Francisco Bay. If you aren’t lucky enough to hold a ticket for the Turf Club facility however, live coverage can been seen on \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E!\r\n\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track is located eleven miles east of San Francisco and is within driving range of the Napa Valley, making it an ideal stop-off for tourists as well as local horseplayers.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tGolden Gate Fields History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tBefore this track as we know it was founded, competitive horse racing took place in this part of California as far back as 1871 when the Oakland Trotting Track opened, only around 2 miles away from the current home of racing in the area.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere was a ban on horse racing in the state from 1911, something which was repealed in 1933 and then just before the War Golden Gate Fields built a new grandstand nearby with marshland filled in to create the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first meet at the new facility was held on February 1, 1941 although the US Navy took over the area to use for storing landing craft destined for the Pacific. Racing later resumed after WWII was over.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tGolden Gate Fields stayed under the same ownership for more than two decades until it was bought by Magna Entertainment Corp, though they filed for bankruptcy in 2009 allowing the racing-oriented Stronach Group to purchase the facility in summer 2011.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tGolden Gate Fields Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is a one-mile synthetic Tapeta oval surface, formally made up of sandy loam with a 1000-feet run from the final turn to the wire. The turf course is bigger than most at 9\u002F10 of a mile, sitting inside the dirt track and by the lake. Over 1,400 thoroughbreds can be stabled at Golden Gate Fields.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSan Francisco Mile (Grade 3) – 4yo & over, one mile on turf ($100,000, April)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Berkeley Handicap (Grade 3) – 3yo & over, 8½ furlongs ($100,000, Labor Day Weekend)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t All American Stakes (Grade 3) – 3yo & over, one mile ($100,000, October)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t El Camino Real Derby (Listed Race) – 3yo’s only over 9 furlongs ($100,000, February)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager At Golden Gate Fields With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the popular California track, don’t forget you can wager on races at GGF with TVG. Rosecroft\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tRosecroft Raceway hosts harness racing in Fort Washington, Maryland, and has done since its inception back in 1949.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track was entrusted with part of the Breeders Crown from 1984 to 1988 and from 1990 to 1995 it hosted the Messenger Stakes which is the middle leg of the Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRosecroft sits only a half-hour drive from Washington DC and, given its position right on the I-495, is often referred to as the Raceway by the Beltway.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as its live racing meets Rosecroft is open to the public for simulcast racing meaning that bettors can enjoy the facilities and wager on races from around North America each day. Over 8,000 racing fans can be seated at the facility and there is room for just under 6,000 cars too.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRosecroft History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPlans were afoot in 1947 to have a harness racetrack in Maryland and, after some negotiation; Rosecroft was chosen as the preferred site.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHorsebreeder William E. Miller founded Rosecroft Raceway in 1949 with the opening night (May 27\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\u002Fsup\u003E) being attended by over 6,000 people and attracting wagers totalling more than $160,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRosecroft, owned by jockeys, trainers and breeders, was renowned for luxury with every aspect of it pure class and the facility costing over $800,000 to build ($8.4million in 2018 money).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCrowds began to grow at the popular venue and in 1953 the track hosted a total of 192,585 for the year – the biggest attendance of any harness track in the state. Horsemen from across the States moved to Maryland in the 50’s in order to be able to compete at Rosecroft against the best horses in the business.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRosecroft started hosting the annual yearling Standardbred horse sales as well as the yearly Maryland Sire Stakes Races, initiatives intended to promote Maryland-bred horses.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSince the death of the track’s founder it has changed hands on a number of occasions and it currently owned by the Stronach Group (since 2016), having been in the hands of Mark Vogel, Weisman’s Colt Enterprises, Cloverleaf Enterprises and Penn National Gaming from 1987 onwards.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Bets At Rosecroft With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track at Rosecroft, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. The track is surrounded by hotels and is less than a 25-minute drive from Sacramento International Airport.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as the quality harness racing on show during the season, Cal Expo still hosts the California State Fair on the current site every year in either August or September with thoroughbred, quarter horse and Arabian racing all taking place during the festivities.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Cal Expo History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The track was first built back in 1906, primarily for horse racing, on the site of the California Exposition. The exposition, known as Cal Expo, was setup to promote California’s farming and industry and lends its name to this track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAuto racing also took place on the site in 1907, 1912 and again from 1946 to 1970 inclusive though horse racing was always its intended use as a track. The expo moved to downtown Sacramento in 1968 when the old California State Fairgrounds were closed. The new track has been in use since 1970 and remains a hugely popular visitor attraction in the city.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Although the meet between October and May features more than 50 race days, the biggest races to look out for \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002F\"\u003Eon TVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E are:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCA State Fair Open Mule Challenge Earlene McCabe Derby Governor’s Handicap The Hazel Lucas Stakes The Jack Clifford Straight From The Gate Futurity\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Place Your Cal Expo Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Now you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003E\r\n\t\tUpcoming Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\"\u003E\r\n\t\t\t\there\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tMeadowlands Race Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tOpened in the 1970s, the first harness race was held on September 1, 1976, while thoroughbred racing began on September 6, 1977. Since its opening, autumn has been dedicated to thoroughbreds, while the rest of the year focuses on standardbreds or harness horses. Since 1981, the Meadowlands Race Track has been the location of Hambletonian, the second leg of the Trotting Triple Crown.\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tMeadowlands Race Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLike many comparable tracks in the United States, the main track has a one-mile circumference and surrounds a smaller turf course – intended for Thoroughbreds only, which is 7 furlongs in length. With a span of exactly 3\u002F16ths of a mile from the top of the stretch to the finish line and a distance of exactly 1\u002F16th of a mile from the finish line to the beginning of the first turn, the dimensions of the track are considered typical for an American-based course. The Meadowlands harness racing track is 90 feet wide, while the width of the turf course is 80 feet.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t The main structures and surrounding the grounds were designed by the Philadelphia-based architectural firm of Ewing Cole, which has designed a number of horse racing tracks around the world, as well as Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia. Live action happens one or two Sundays per month along with every Monday and Tuesday, post time being at midday.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t35-40 race days are planned in during this time with results listed \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults'\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, though the track is open each day for simulcast racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Portland Meadows\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tAlthough racing has existed in this location since 1946, the track benefits these days from the strong ownership of the Stronach Group, the Ontario-based group having taken over the track in summer 2011.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track puts on both quarter horse and thoroughbred racing, though revenue is supplemented by the hosting of outdoor music concerts and running championships in the summer months.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPortland Meadows sits on the banks of the Columbia Slough, a small waterway which acts as a tributary to the Willamette River and is only 6 miles from downtown Portland, Oregon on the I-5. Portland International Airport is less than eight miles away.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPortland Meadows History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tConstruction first began on this site back in 1945 under the supervision of William P. Kyne. His participation in the project was significant as he was instrumental in the legalization of pari-mutuel wagering in California earlier in 1933.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track opened its doors to the public on September 14, 1946 when a crowd of over 10,000 were there to mark the occasion.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAn important part of the track’s history was its implementation of a high powered light system which meant Portland Meadows was the very first US thoroughbred track to offer night racing.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe early history of the track isn’t all good though and problems occurred in 1948 when the Vanport Flood, a natural event which destroyed the town of Vanport City, caused $250,000 worth of damage to the track and it took a while to recover from this.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter a brief period hosting greyhound races in 1956, the track carried on as a thoroughbred racing venue and all was good until another disaster struck. On April 25, 1970, the grandstand was completely destroyed by fire and although thankfully no lives were lost it did mean the premature closing of the meet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFollowing a rebuild completed in 1971, local crowds once again supported the track to the hilt when well over 12,000 attended its reopening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSome star quality was introduced to the Meadows in the eighties when Gary Stevens arrived and was leading rider at the track in ’81 and ’82. Stevens went on to major worldwide success, winning three Kentucky Derby’s and Group One races in Europe.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAlthough purses have gradually declined at the track over the years it remains an important part of the community and, in 2016, Portland Meadows Poker opened up as a licensed casino. It is hoped this development will eventually mean bigger purses on the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPortland Meadows Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPortland Meadows has a standard one-mile dirt oval with two chutes allowing differing start distances. There is no turf facility.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe standout race at this track is the Portland Mile, a race for four-year-olds and over with a purse of $25,000. Horses from both Oregon and California tend to take part on the dirt for an event which takes place in late January.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe supporting card features the Donna Jensen Memorial, the Columbia River, the Revillew Slew Starter and the Mount Hood Handicap.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager At Portland Meadows With Us At TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about Portland Meadows, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Race Track\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Nestled in the beautiful landscape of Vancouver, Canada,Hastings Race Track has been capturing the imagination of Vancouverites and out-of-towners alike for more than a century, showcasing live, seasonal thoroughbred racing and year-round simulcast racing set against picturesque mountain and waterfront views. Over the years, it has played host to a slew of prestigious stakes events, including British Columbia Derby, the Sadie Diamond Futurity, Jack Diamond Futurity, Ballerina Breeders Cup, and the BC Breeders Cup Oaks.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Originally called East Park when it opened for business in 1889, Hastings Racetrack is a now a wholly owned subsidiary of Great Canadian Gaming Corporation (GCGC), a leading casino and gaming operator, as well as the largest community-based gaming management company in western Canada. In 2008, just four years after seizing control, the GCGC added a 600-slot permanent gaming facility to the grounds. That same year, it also celebrated the grand opening of the River Rock Casino Resort in Richmond.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Including simulcasts from many of the world’s most prestigious tracks, 600,000 guests wager upwards of $150 million on more than 40,000 races each year. The inaugural season included a total of 13 race days, a number which has since grown to 31. Fonner Park Race Track was originally built to host the county fair, with horse racing to take place only on days when the fair wasn't open. Racing quickly took center stage, though, and the venue expanded a few times over the years. The facility put additions on the grandstand four times, added five barns for horses in the 1960s, put up a big red barn in 1970, and constructed a clubhouse soon after.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t A 7-year-old gelding, Wenga, set the track record of 2:30.4 for 1 7\u002F16 miles on May 1, 1968.
