Charles Town is one of the busiest tracks in the country with over 200 race days per year, running generally on a 5-day week with full details of each race \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002F\"\u003Eon TVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCharles Town plays host to the Sprint Festival with four open stakes races worth $500,000, as well as the West Virginia Breeders’ Classics and the Charles Town Classic which is an important Grade 2 race.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe latter named race is worth anything between $500,000 and $1,000,000 depending on the graded status of the winner.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as a full schedule of live racing, Charles Town provides bettors with over 3,000 slot machines and table games on site to keep everyone entertained every day of the week.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tCharles Town History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Charles Town Race Track opened for business in Jefferson County way back in December 1933. After West Virginia legalized racing and parimutuel betting, Charles Town was the first track to open in the state with a 3000-seat heated grandstand and a 200-seat restaurant.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWe are perhaps lucky to have Charles Town given that it was built during the Great Depression, lost money in its first two years in operation and could have easily closed for good. After the influential Albert J. Boyle bought the track however he attracted big gamblers from Washington and Baltimore who changed its fortunes for decades.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWhen another change of ownership occurred in 1964, the track installed lights for night racing and this is still something the track is famous for to this day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track was in financial trouble again by the 90’s but, in 1996, West Virginia voters approved the advent of lottery machines inside state tracks and so once more there was a renaissance for Charles Town and as of today, these machines bring in most of the revenue for this venture.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tCharles Town Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track at Charles Town is a conventional dirt track of around ¾ of a mile, also featuring a chute. There is no turf track at this venue. The tight nature of the turns at Charles Town make for exciting sprint racing, especially during the Sprint Festival in early summer which is somewhat of a spectacle here.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tBiggest Races\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCharles Town Classic (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F8 miles, four-year-olds and over (April).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCharles Town Invitational Dash – four-and-a-half furlongs, three-year-olds and over (June).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLady Charles Town – four-and-a-half furlongs, three-year-old fillies (June).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWest Virginia Sprint Derby – four-and-a-half furlongs, three-year-olds (June).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tRed Legend Stakes – seven furlongs, three-year-olds (June).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tWest Virginia Breeders’ Classic – one and 1\u002F8 miles, three-year-olds and over (October).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\tBet Charles Town With TVG!\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Find the latest results from the track \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults'\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Gulfstream Park West\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tGulfstream Park West meets are held at Calder Race Course in Miami Gardens, only 20 minutes from the famous Gulfstream Park by the beach.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track has become synonymous with an eclectic mix of jockeys from around Latin America and the Caribbean such as Alex Solis, Jose Santos, Eddie Castro and Abel Castellano who have all benefited greatly from their experience at the track over the years.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe stable area can house 1,800 horses, has a receiving barn and also living quarters for horsemen as part of the impressive 220-acre property.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLocated right next door to the Miami Dolphins’ stadium, Gulfstream Park West is within 20 minutes of Miami International Airport as well as Fort Lauderdale Airport.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tGulfstream Park West History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSummer racing in Florida was the brainchild of Stephen A. Calder back in the mid-1960’s and, the Florida Legislature having approved a bill allowing it, a fall racing meet was arranged for the first time at Tropical Race Track, Miami, in 1965.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tConstruction began at what was to be called Calder Race Course in 1970 and on May 6, 1971 the track hosted its first racing meet. By this time the new owners of Tropical Park had announced their intentions to switch all racing to Calder and hence their track ceased operating in 1972.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy the 1980’s many expansions had taken place at Calder and in 1992 the first “Festival of the Sun” was hosted. Simulcasting was launched on the site in 1997 and the resulting revenue from this saw further development and success.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tCalder’s new found prominence resulted in Churchill Downs acquiring the track in January 1999 for a cool $86million with the Florida Million and the Summit of Speed introduced to the racing calendar.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMore recent times have seen some name changes at the track, the site being renamed Calder Casino & Race Course in 2009 with the grand opening of the casino in January 2010 but after Churchill Downs’ sale of the lease of racing operations in 2014, the track has become known as Gulfstream Park West.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tGulfstream Park West Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track is a standard, one-mile oval with 1\u002F4 and 7\u002F8 chutes. The racing surface is made up of both sand and clay. The turf track sits inside of the main course and is 7\u002F8 of a mile in length, made up of Bermuda grass.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe Florida Million is made up of 8 races for Florida-bred types at the end of the year. The first harness meet was held in the Spring of 1953, making 2008 it's 59th Season. Known as the pioneer track for being the first 5\u002F8ths mile track in the country, Hazel Park Raceway has attracted some of the nation's top drivers, trainers and equines since its inception. The track was a dual-breed facility from 1949 through 1984; and has hosted harness racing exclusively since 1985.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t The track's record for live handle and attendance occurred on July 12, 1975 when 15,372 patrons wagered $1,425,478. The record $2.00 payoff at any harness track was recorded at Hazel Park on September 17, 1988 when the \"Twin-Super\" wager (selecting in exact order, the first four finishers in two races) paid $1,243,053.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t During the past several years, Hazel Park has hosted the prestigous $150,000 Wm. C Connors Memorial 3 year old open trot and the Night of Champions on which the state's elite 2 & 3 year olds compete for $1,000,000 in purse money. The track's nightly overnight events have an industry-wide reputation as being some of the most competitive racing to be found anywhere. Anchored by Michigan's strong foundation in harness racing and buoyed by a superlative influx of racing stables from southern Ontario to California, Florida and the Midwest. Racing at Hazel Park has always been considered among the nation's finest.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t In 1996, state legislation permitted full-card Simulcasting enabling the track to virtually be open for business year round seven days a week, noon till midnight. Now, in addition to the outstanding live racing, patrons may view and wager on all major harness and thoroughbred tracks across the country. The Triple Crown, Breeder's Cup and Breeder's Crown, Little Brown Jug and The Hambletonian are all now standard fare. On Saturday May 3 2008 Hazel Park attracted over 14,000 race fans to wager and watch te Kentucky Derby via simulcast.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t The Bridge Lounge Several recent improvements have been added for customer and horsemen convenience including: a passing lane, a casual park-setting picnic area, several banks of 42\" plasma TVs, the very popular Top of the Park Grill, the Bridge Lounge, & the Homestretch Bar. The track is situated only 10 miles from Des Moines and just over 300 miles from downtown Chicago.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track has traditionally run an April to October season with many recognisable races run there; these include the Cornhusker Handicap, the Iowa Oaks and the Iowa Derby (details below).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAs well as thoroughbreds and quarter horses, many other animals including ostriches have been known to compete at what is a racing mad venue!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAside from looking after race goers, the site caters for those with an interest in gaming. The on-site casino has 1,900 slot machines as well as tables for blackjack, poker and roulette. Music concerts are also hosted at Prairie Meadows from time to time.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPrairie Meadows History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tPari-mutuel betting was legalized by the state of Iowa in 1983 and the following year Prairie Meadows gained a license from the Iowa Gaming Commission with ground eventually being broken on the project in 1987.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce fully built, Prairie Meadows could host its first racing day and did so on March 1, 1989 however the track went on to lose money in its early years of operation and even filed for bankruptcy at the end of 1991.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBecause of this, racing was suspended in 1992 but wasn’t away for long and returned the following season with some of the track’s problems having been ironed out.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tLike many North American tracks, live racing alone wasn’t seen as viable at Prairie Meadows and in a landmark vote on May 17, 1994, Polk County approved the installation of slot machines at the venue which saw it open as a racino on April 1, 1995.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track flourished after that and by 2004 Prairie Meadows added casino gaming tables, the resulting financial success leading to the venue expanding the facility in January 2005 at a cost of $60million.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tPart of Prairie Meadows’ success is that it is owned by Polk County and operated by a board of directors who run on a non-profit basis. The cash amounts generated on site are given to various local projects around the Des Moines area and this initiative is something the Iowa Events Center owes itself to, among other things.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy mid-2008, Prairie Meadows was pulling in close to $200million per year in basic revenues which has helped racing flourish there.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPrairie Meadows Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThis venue has a one mile dirt track which also has a chute for quarter horse races. To counteract this Vernon Downs, along with many other race tracks around the country, added gaming and simulcast racing to their offering in order to add more revenue as well as offering entertainment acts.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFollowing years of uncertainty and the passing of a bill in New York State which did not allow for lower taxes for racinos, Vernon Downs closed its doors to the public. Seabiscuit was even beaten around Laurel Park when finishing second in the Laurel Stakes in 1938.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tMany years of success followed with Hall of Fame jockeys and top racing talent having plied their trade around this track to great acclaim.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe inaugural running of the Maryland Million, a program designed to show off the state’s breeding prowess, was held at Laurel Park in 1986 and ran strong for years.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThere was a failed attempt to introduce slot machines to Laurel Park in 2013, however the race-minded Stronach Group announced that to counter this loss of potential revenue they would use the Maryland Racetrack Facility Redevelopment Account to fund racing and that is working for now with over 100 live dates in the calendar.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tLaurel Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe dirt track at Laurel is a nine-furlong oval, 75 feet in width and with a 1,344 foot run to the wire from the final turn. Bet on horse racing by visiting TVG’s\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fraces\"\u003E\r\n\t\tUpcoming Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\r\n\t or find out the latest information about TVG\r\n\t\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\"\u003E\r\n\t\there\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tHawthorne Race Track History\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t In 1905, horse racing was banned in Chicago, leading to the closure of Hawthorne Race Course. In 1909, the track was sold to Thomas Carey who tried to reopen the track twice but was stopped by the sheriff's department and the local police. But in 1916, the track ran a 13-day meeting which included the American Derby. That would be the last race until 1922.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t In 1922, the track reopened legally for a 13-day race meeting. In 1923, the meet expanded again to 25 days. The Chicago Business Men's Racing Association took over racing operations in 1924 and ran a 52-day meet in the fall. This same year a new clubhouse was constructed at Hawthorne Race Course, and a form of pari-mutuel betting was introduced. By 1927, the race track was gaining prominence on the national scene.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t The track introduced Daily Double wagering to Chicago and used a new infrared timer in the early 1930s. In 1936, the track began the Chicago racing season with a spring meet. The Hawthorne Race Course continued to advance in the 1930s and 1940s, taking over the racing dates of Lincoln Fields Racetrack as well as racing earlier in the spring. The track also introduced races restricted to Illinois-bred horses.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Turf racing returned to Hawthorne in 1948 with the renovation of the racing strip and the introduction of a six-furlong turf course. In 1959, a new clubhouse was opened with vastly expanded seating to serve the racing needs of the Chicago market. The track continued to thrive during the 1960s and 1970s, but it had crested in attendance and the attendance slowly began to drop.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t In 1985, Arlington Park burned to the ground and Hawthorne Race Course gained all summer dates except Arlington Million day. In 1986, 1987 and 1988 the track also held these summertime meetings. The horse racing track continues to do well having a very good 1990s. Hawthorne is now second tier to Arlington Park, the premier thoroughbred track in Chicago.\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tHawthorne Race Track Details\r\n\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t\tHawthorne Race Course has a one-mile dirt oval and a seven-furlong turf oval. One of the longest in the country, the main track home stretch is 1,320 feet. Spend a day at the horse racing track with friendly staff and great food. From casual to corporate, you can choose an amenity package to fit any event with a variety of room and dining options. Hawthorne Race Course is also able to host many outdoors events including concerts, festivals, RV shows, reunions, art fairs and thoroughbred racing.  The track does well at keeping its old fashioned charm in what is an easy-going atmosphere.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EDespite the tranquil feel of the place however, racing is frenetic and high quality with some of Kentucky’s most important stakes races run at the venue (list below).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EEllis Park is 120 miles from Louisville, Kentucky, the home of the Kentucky Derby and is an important part of racing in the state despite the fact that had the states been split according to the way the Ohio River now runs in the modern day it would actually sit in Indiana.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEllis Park History\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EA place of historical interest, Ellis Park was built by the Green River Jockey Club way back in 1922 and initially held harness racing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EHaving been acquired by a new owner in 1925, the track which was then known as Dade Park began to improve as a tote board was installed alongside a new grandstand and other facilities.  After decades of mixed success, the track was renamed Ellis Park in 1954.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter the track was sold out of the Ellis family in 1985, more renovation was done before it was moved on to the Racing Corporation of America in 1989, who in turn sold it to Churchill Downs in 1998.  They handed the facility over in 2006 to Ron Geary.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWith closure a real possibility in 2008 owing to a dispute over revenues gained from simulcast racing, a deal was eventually struck and, to much relief among horsemen and fans alike no doubt, the track continued to trade and remains a strong entity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Ch2\u003EEllis Park Track Details\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EThe dirt track at Ellis Park is a little larger than most at 9 furlongs, a move which came about after it was designed to emulate the surface at Saratoga in New York.  There are chutes to accommodate seven furlong and one mile races and the mile-long turf course sits to the inside of The track is open for simulcast racing on all but three days during this schedule also.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Tampa Bay Downs\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tTampa Bay Downs is the only thoroughbred race track on Florida’s west coast and was raised in profile in 2007 when Hall of Fame trainer Carl Nafzger successfully ran his Champion Two-Year-Old colt Street Sense in the Tampa Bay Derby en route to winning the Kentucky Derby.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter this, fellow HoF handler Bill Mott used the track as the starting point of filly Royal Delta’s 3yo campaign here on \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com'\u003ETVG\u003C\u002Fa\u003E before winning the Breeders’ Cup Distaff as well star 4yo Drosselmeyer before winning the Breeders’ Cup Classic in 2011.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tTampa Bay Downs History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tWith development masterminded by investors Harvey Myers and Colonel Matt J. Winn, the track opened up as the West Coast Jockey Club in 1926 and operated as such until 1943 when the US Army took it over to use it as a training facility during the War.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track was given an overhaul three years later; renamed Sunshine Park and adapted with electric starting gates, photo finishes and a tote board. A further name change occurred in 1965 as the facility became Florida Downs and Turf Club and carried on largely unchanged until 1980 when it became what we know it as now – Tampa Bay Downs.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tFrom 1983 and for 20 years thereafter, Tampa operated Arabian races as well as thoroughbred heats with only a dirt track at the facility, though by 1998 a turf track was added to diversify the range of races offered.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tStars both human and equine to have graced the track at Tampa include Julie Krone, Street Sense and Any Given Sunday and this has led to some significant success with over $10.9million handled on Tampa Bay Derby day in 2007 and again in 2011.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tA poker room was added to the facilities in 2003 and in time for the 2011-2012 season a new tool was added when Trakus was installed – a system for tracking the exact position of runners on TV monitors.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTampa Bay Downs continues to go from strength to strength and can yet be the starting point for potential three-year-old Triple Crown contenders, especially during Festival Day each season.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tTampa Bay Downs Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track at Tampa is a standard dirt oval of one mile round with a seven furlong turf track to the inner which has a quarter-mile chute.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tTampa Bay’s big meet is the Festival Day in March which features the following races:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTampa Bay Derby (Grade 2) - Gates open at the track at 5.30PM for a post time of 6.45PM and all results will show up right \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fresults'\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E throughout the meet.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tAbout Retama Park\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tRetama Park hosts various types on its two tracks located at Selma, Texas, on the outskirts of San Antonio which is around 19 miles away.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe track has been hosting live racing since 1995 and remains open on non-racing days for simulcasting, allowing bettors to place wagers on races from elsewhere round the country on a daily basis.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRetama Park History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe track opened for business on April 7, 1995 and had a successful first year which included making constant improvements such as offering twin trifecta wagering and suprfecta wagering.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBig increases in revenue were posted in 1996 as the track consolidated its position and by its third season in 1997, the first mixed meet was hosted.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy 1998 the track was reporting a daily handle of $378,000 on average for its mixed meet and an incredible $1,000,000 average for the thoroughbred meet in the fall.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tJust before the turn of the millennium, Retama announced plans to expand and introduce a lavish new area called the Players Club for their Turf and Field Club members. This opened to coincide with the start of the mixed meet in April 1999 to great acclaim and by October that year, daily thoroughbred handles had topped $2,000,000.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThis century things have gotten even better and the track remains very popular both with locals and out-of-towners who flock to watch the live action.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tRetama Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main track at Retama Park is a one-mile dirt oval with two chutes offering varying start distances, while there is a seven furlong turf course to the inside. There is a 990-feet run from the final turn to the wire down the homestretch.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tSix stakes races are run during Retama’s thoroughbred meet, namely:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Fiesta Mile ($50,000, August)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Texas Horse Racing Hall of Fame Stakes ($50,000, August)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Darby’s Daughter Division of the Clarence Scharbauer Jr. Texas Stallion Stakes ($65,000, August)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t My Dandy Division of the Clarence Scharbauer Jr. Texas Stallion Stakes ($65,000, August)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t La Senorita Stakes ($75,000, September)\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t El Joven Stakes ($75,000, September)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tWager At Retama Park With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. Monmouth Park was once again closed and this time the land sold off with the future looking pretty bleak.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tAfter a huge gap in time, Monmouth Park was re-opened in 1946 following intense pressure on the state to legalize pari-mutuel betting, which they did in the end with almost 19,000 turning up for the track’s opening day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 1950 turf racing was held at the track for the first time and the following year one of Monmouth’s biggest races, the Molly Pitcher Handicap, became the first race ever to be televised in color.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tBy 1997 Monmouth had reached new heights with that year’s Haskell Invitational day drawing a crowd of over 39,000 who between them wagered almost $10million on the day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tIn 2001however the bar was raised once again on Haskell day when a massive crowd of over 47,000 turned up to make the annual attendance at the track over 750,000, figures not seen since 1989.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tToday Monmouth Park remains one of the most popular race tracks in the entire country, something befitting its near 150-year history.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tMonmouth Park Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tThe main dirt track at Monmouth is nice and wide at 100 feet. It is a one mile dirt oval topped off with a mixture of silt, clay and loam.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tTo the inside is the turf course, slightly shorter and narrower at 90 feet and 7\u002F8 of a mile and made up of bluegrass and Manhattan rye grass.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe public get a chance to see the horses in the English Walking ring, a beautiful area of the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tBiggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tUnited Nations Stakes (Grade 1) – one and 3\u002F8 miles, three-year-olds and older (turf) (July).\r\n\t\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\r\n\tHaskell Invitational (Grade 1) – one and 1\u002F8 miles, three-year-olds (July).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Molly Pitcher Stakes (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds and older (July).\r\n\t\u003Cbr\u002F\u003E\r\n\t Monmouth Cup (Grade 2) – one and 1\u002F16 miles, three-year-olds and older (July).\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\tPlace Your Monmouth Park Bets With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tNow you know all about Monmouth, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. CA 91007, USA\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Contact\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t info@santaanita.com\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Racing Dates\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Live racing gets going at Santa Anita at Christmas time and runs right through to June with over 15 days of live racing planned each month. Post time is usually 12.30PM with many stakes races scheduled in.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t About Santa Anita\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Located in Arcadia, California around six miles from Pasadena and 16 from downtown LA, Santa Anita Park hosts top class thoroughbred horse racing in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita has many Grade 1 and Grade 2 races and has hosted the Breeders’ Cup eight times, most recently in 2016 when Arrogate won a thrilling renewal of the Breeders’ Cup Classic against strong favorite California Chrome in the finale.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe Park encompasses more than 320 acres of land and features a 26,000-capacity grandstand which is over 1,000 feet long. Given its popularity, the infield is open to race goers dramatically increasing the capacity on race day.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOn its record day back in 1993, Santa Anita Park announced a handle of $36,264,799 on a single day which contributed to the billions wagered at the track since its opening.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita History\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Santa Anita Park started life as part of Rancho Santa Anita, something which was bought by Scotsman Hugo Reid and later acquired by breeder Lucky Baldwin who built a race track by what is now modern day Arcadia. The original facility opened in 1904, closed in 1909 and even burned down in 1912.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tOnce horse racing was allowed again in the state and pari-mutuel betting was legalized in 1933, several working groups came together to form the Los Angeles Turf Club who opened the present track on Christmas Day 1934.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe first Santa Anita Handicap, already worth $100,000, was run in 1935 and over the years people of the caliber of Carry Grant and Bing Crosby became shareholders in the track.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tThe amazing Seabiscuit was a visitor at the track and won the Santa Anita Handicap on his final career start, just before racing was suspended due to World War II.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita went from strength to strength through the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s and hosted equestrian events at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tHaving hosted 8 Breeders’ Cup Championships as well as numerous Santa Anita Derby winners having gone on to land the Kentucky Derby, the track remains one of the premier race courses anywhere in the world.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Santa Anita Track Details\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t The main track is a one-mile dirt oval which has a large, 9\u002F10 of a mile turf track to the inside. A key feature at Santa Anita is its extra hillside turf track to the north-west of the main track, crossing over the dirt and meeting the main turf track. It is used for races of around 6½ furlongs in distance.\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Biggest Races\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Many big races are staged at Santa Anita with information on our blog given in the lead-up, something you can find \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.tvg.com\u002Fblog\u002F\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Just a few of the big race highlights at Santa Anita are:\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\tSanta Anita Derby (Grade 1) – 3yo, 9 furlongs ($1,000,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+, 10 furlongs ($600,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Anita Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 8½ furlongs ($400,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t Santa Margarita Invitational Handicap (Grade 1) – 4yo+ fillies & mares, 9 furlongs ($500,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t FrontRunner Stakes (Grade 1) – 2yo, 8½ furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\t\r\n\t American Oaks (Grade 1) – 3yo fillies, 10 furlongs ($300,000)\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Stay Up to Date With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\tHead over to our \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fnews.tvg.com\u002Fcategory\u002Ftop-regions\u002Fsanta-anita-park\u002F\"\u003ESanta Anita News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E page to get the latest news updates!\r\n\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003E\r\n\t\u003Ch2\u003E\r\n\t\t Wager At Santa Anita With TVG!\r\n\t\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\r\n\t Now you know all about the track, don’t forget you can wager on races there with TVG. /* POPUP SHOW */
@keyframes showPopup {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.7);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.7);
    -o-transform: scale(0.7);
    transform: scale(0.7);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; } }

@-webkit-keyframes showPopup {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.7);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.7);
    -o-transform: scale(0.7);
    transform: scale(0.7);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; } }

@keyframes hidePopup {
  from {
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.6);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.6);
    -o-transform: scale(0.6);
    transform: scale(0.6);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 0; } }

@-webkit-keyframes hidePopup {
  from {
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.6);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.6);
    -o-transform: scale(0.6);
    transform: scale(0.6);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 0; } }

  #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper

/* POPUP SHOW */
@keyframes showContainerFromLeft {
  from {
    left: -500px;
    opacity: 0; }
  to {
    left: 0px;
    opacity: 1; } }

@-webkit-keyframes showContainerFromLeft {
  from {
    left: -500px;
    opacity: 0; }
  to {
    left: 0px;
    opacity: 1; } }

@keyframes hideContainerFromLeft {
  from {
    left: 0px;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    left: -500px;
    opacity: 0; } }

@-webkit-keyframes hideContainerFromLeft {
  from {
    left: 0px;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    left: -500px;
    opacity: 0; } }

@keyframes showContainerFromRight {
  from {
    right: -500px;
    opacity: 0; }
  to {
    right: 0px;
    opacity: 1; } }

  from {
    right: -500px;
    opacity: 0; }
  to {
    right: 0px;
    opacity: 1; } }

    right: 0px;

  to {
    opacity: 0;
    right: -500px; } }

    right: 0px;

  to {

    right: -500px; } }

  from {
    bottom: 0px;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    opacity: 0;
    bottom: -500px; } }

@keyframes showContainer {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.7);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.7);
    -o-transform: scale(0.7);
    transform: scale(0.7);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; } }

@-webkit-keyframes showContainer {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.7);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.7);
    -o-transform: scale(0.7);
    transform: scale(0.7);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom; } }

@keyframes hideContainer {
  from {
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.6);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.6);
    -o-transform: scale(0.6);
    transform: scale(0.6);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 0; } }

@-webkit-keyframes hideContainer {
  from {
    -webkit-transform: scale(1);
    -moz-transform: scale(1);
    -o-transform: scale(1);
    transform: scale(1);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 1; }
  to {
    -webkit-transform: scale(0.6);
    -moz-transform: scale(0.6);
    -o-transform: scale(0.6);
    transform: scale(0.6);
    -webkit-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;
    -o-transform-origin: top bottom;
    transform-origin: top bottom;
    opacity: 0; } }

  from {
    opacity: 0;
    position: fixed; }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    position: fixed; } }

  from {
    opacity: 0;
    position: fixed; }

    opacity: 1;
    position: fixed; } }

    opacity: 0;
    position: fixed; } }

  background: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  display: block;
  opacity: 1;

  margin: auto;
  right: auto;
  bottom: auto;
  top: auto;
  position: fixed;
  border-radius: 4px;
  overflow: visible; }
  #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper
.sl-frame-component.sl-container.sl-position-center-middle {
    left: 0;
    right: 0;
    bottom: 0;
    top: 0;
    position: fixed; }
    #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper
.sl-frame-component.sl-container.sl-position-center-middle.sl-show-animation {
      -webkit-animation-name: showContainer;
      animation-name: showContainer;
      -webkit-animation-duration: 0.3s;
      animation-duration: 0.3s;
      animation-fill-mode: forwards; }

.sl-frame-component.sl-container.sl-position-center-middle.sl-show-animation .sl-item-background-shade {
        -webkit-animation-name: showContainerShadow;
        animation-name: showContainerShadow;
        -webkit-animation-duration: 0.4s;
        animation-duration: 0.4s;
        animation-fill-mode: forwards;
        -webkit-transform: scale(15, 5);
        -moz-transform: scale(15, 5);
        -o-transform: scale(15, 5);
        transform: scale(15, 5);

        -moz-transform-origin: top bottom;

.sl-frame-component.sl-html-container {
  background: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  display: block;
  opacity: 1;
  left: auto;
  margin: auto;
  right: auto;
  bottom: auto;
  top: auto;
  position: fixed;
  border-radius: 4px;
  overflow: visible; }
  #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper
.sl-frame-component.sl-html-container.sl-position-center-middle {
    left: 0;
    right: 0;
    bottom: 0;
    top: 0;
    position: fixed; }
    #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper
.sl-frame-component.sl-html-container.sl-position-center-middle.sl-show-animation {
      -webkit-animation-name: showContainer;
      animation-name: showContainer;
      -webkit-animation-duration: 0.3s;
      animation-duration: 0.3s;
      animation-fill-mode: forwards; }
      #slContainer .sl-views-wrapper
.sl-frame-component.sl-html-container.sl-position-center-middle.sl-show-animation .sl-item-background-shade {
        -webkit-animation-name: showContainerShadow;
        animation-name: showContainerShadow;
        -webkit-animation-duration: 0.4s;
        animation-duration: 0.4s;

 <script>
    function sendGTM(e, clickedLink, route) {
      if (clickedLink !== 'doNotSell') {
        e.preventDefault();
        e.stopPropagation();
      }
      
      window.mediatorChannels.base.dispatch({type: 'FOOTER_LINK_CLICK', payload: { clickedLink: clickedLink}});
      if (clickedLink === "careers" || clickedLink === "FanDuel" || clickedLink === "Support Center") {
        window.open(route, '_blank');
      } else if (clickedLink === 'email' || clickedLink === "californiaPolicy") {
        window.location.assign(route);
      } else {
        window.mediator.dispatch('TVG4_NAVIGATION', { route: route });
      }
    }
</script>
